title: Mitigating microplastic-induced organ Damage: Mechanistic insights from the microplastic-macrophage axes
abstract: We live in a world increasingly dominated by plastic, leading to the generation of microplastic particles that pose significant global health concerns. Microplastics can enter the body via ingestion, inhalation, and direct contact, accumulating in various tissues and potentially causing harm. Despite this, the specific cellular mechanisms and signaling pathways involved remain poorly understood. Macrophages are essential in absorbing, distributing, and eliminating microplastics, playing a key role in the body's defense mechanisms. Recent evidence highlights oxidative stress signaling as a key pathway in microplastic-induced macrophage dysfunction. The accumulation of microplastics generates reactive oxygen species (ROS), disrupting normal macrophage functions and exacerbating inflammation and organ damage. This review serves as the first comprehensive examination of the interplay between microplastics, macrophages, and oxidative stress. It discusses how oxidative stress mediates macrophage responses to microplastics and explores the interactions with gut microbiota. Additionally, it reviews the organ damage resulting from alterations in macrophage function mediated by microplastics and offers a novel perspective on the defense, assessment, and treatment of microplastic-induced harm from the viewpoint of macrophages.

sections.title: Introduction
sections.text: Microplastics (MP) refer to plastic particles with a diameter of less than 5 mm, while nanoplastics (NP) are defined as plastic particles with a diameter of less than 1 μm. These small plastic molecules primarily originate from the degradation of plastic items, wear and tear of automobile tires, washing of clothing, weathering of paint coatings, and leakage of pre-production pellets and powders [1,2]. As plastics are widely used in various fields, we gradually find ourselves living in a world filled with plastic. Since the mid-20th century, the production and use of plastics have exploded due to the development of industrialization [1]. According to statistics, global plastic production reached 400.3 million tons in 2022, with an annual growth rate of 2.4 % [3]. If this trajectory continues, it is estimated that around 12 billion metric tons of plastic waste could accumulate by 2050 [4]. The widespread presence of microplastics not only threatens ecosystems but may also have potential impacts on human health [1]. This growing concern is underscored by the fact that April 22, 2024, marks the 55th Earth Day, with the theme “Planet vs. Plastics,” highlighting that microplastic pollution is a significant global issue. Humans are exposed to, ingest, and inhale a variety of microplastics every day (Fig. 1). Additionally, microplastics have the potential to transfer through the marine food chain to humans [5]. The extensive use of plastic items in production, processing, packaging, and storage [6] has led to microplastics and nanoplastics being found in many food and drinking water sources due to degradation from physical or chemical processes [7]. Currently, there is no relevant legislation to limit their concentration in food, leading to long-term exposure and ingestion of microplastics, which poses a threat to human health and ecological safety. A meta-analysis of existing data indicates that individuals may ingest between 0.10 and 5 g of microplastics per week [8].Fig. 1Degradation of plastics into microplastics and their entry into the human body. Common plastic polymers, including polypropylene, polystyrene, polyethylene terephthalate, polyvinyl chloride, polyethylene, and polyurethane, degrade into microplastics. These microplastics are widely dispersed in the environment, including air, water, and soil. Common plastic polymers, including polypropylene, polystyrene, polyethylene terephthalate, polyvinyl chloride, polyethylene, and polyurethane, degrade into microplastics. These microplastics are widely dispersed in the environment, including air, water, and soil. The primary pathways for their entry into the human body include ingestion through the gastrointestinal tract, inhalation through the lungs, and skin contact. Microplastics can enter the human body typically involve three mechanisms: ingestion through the gastrointestinal tract, inhalation through the lungs, or skin contact [[9], [10], [11]]. Once microplastics enter the body, they can reach the bloodstream and distribute to various organs [12,13]. Different types of microplastics have been found in human tissues such as blood, liver, lungs, placenta, kidneys, spleen, sputum, and feces [14]. Over time, microplastics can build up and remain in the body, potentially causing serious lung damage, liver toxicity, immune system issues, and reproductive toxicity [10,15]. Studies have shown that, in addition to causing direct toxicity, micro/nanoplastics can interact with the mammalian immune system once inside the body, leading to indirect damage [3,5,7,16]. Moreover, microplastics possess a small specific surface area and often contain additives that can effectively adsorb or bind heavy metals, organic pollutants, and viruses, while also promoting the growth of harmful bacteria on their surfaces, increasing potential risks [17,18]. When foreign particles enter the human body at the cellular level, immune cells are among the first responders. Macrophages, a critical component of innate immunity, play an essential role in the intestinal barrier, alveolar-blood barrier, and skin barrier that microplastics must traverse before entering the body [11]. Macrophages can capture specific types of material with diameters up to 10 μm through phagocytosis, thereby minimizing the contamination of other body parts by particulate matter [19]. Additionally, macrophages function as antigen-presenting cells (APCs), facilitating T cell activation, which is crucial for recognition by lymphocytes [20,21]. Beyond their immune and phagocytic functions, macrophages play a part in tissue remodeling, clearing cellular debris, and maintenance of homeostasis [22]. Given the significance of macrophages in immune defense against microplastics, we summarize and discuss the interactions between microplastics and macrophages, as well as the microplastic-gut microbiota-macrophage axis. We focus on the mechanisms by which microplastics promote macrophage toxicity endpoints through changes in intracellular ROS, revealing that the accumulation of microplastics in macrophages can induce ROS production and initiate a cascade of cellular inflammatory signaling, which may lead to unprecedented harmful effects. We review the organ damage caused by microplastic-mediated alterations in macrophage function and explore ways to prevent their harmful effects, focusing on macrophages. Our aim is to enhance understanding of microplastics’ impact on human health.

sections.title: Overview of microplastics
sections.text: Plastics are a variety of synthetic or semi-synthetic polymer materials. Environmental polymer plastics are made up of different chemical polymers, with common examples including polypropylene (PP), polystyrene (PS), polyethylene terephthalate (PET), polyvinyl chloride (PVC), polyethylene (PE), and polyurethane (PUR) [20,23,24]. In addition to the base polymers, these materials often contain additional components, such as additives and plasticizers [25]. As human activities increasingly affect the environment, plastic production and use have continuously increased since the 1950s, coupled with poor waste management, resulting in global pollution [26]. In 1972, Carpenter et al. first observed tiny plastic particles in the ocean [27]. In 2004, the term “microplastics” was introduced by Thompson et al. [28]. The various environmental exposures throughout the plastic lifecycle have led to small plastics in different shapes (like spheres, fibers, and fragments), sizes (ranging from macro to micron), and compositions [25]. Plastics can be categorized by size into mega plastics (>1 m), large plastics (<1 m), mesoplastics (<2.5 cm), and microplastics (<5 mm) [10]. Microplastics can further degrade into nanoplastics (diameter <1000 nm) [16]. As a global pollutant, microplastics are distributed throughout the Earth's biosphere. On one hand, microplastics are widely present in all types of aquatic environments. Studies have shown that about 70 % of marine debris consists of plastic objects [29]. On the other hand, besides their presence in water environments, microplastics in the atmosphere are also increasing, even affecting local and regional climates, especially in areas with particularly high plastic concentrations in the air [30,31]. Because of their extensive spread and long-lasting nature in the environment, plastics are even referred to as “technofossils”. The potential marking of microplastics as an indicator of the Anthropocene era further underscores the profound impact humans have on the Earth's geological and soil ecosystems [31]. Microplastics can be produced intentionally (primary MP) or formed from larger plastics (secondary MP) through biodegradation and abiotic processes. Notably, abiotic processes primarily involve photodegradation, hydrolysis, mechanical degradation, or thermal degradation [10,20]. Once plastic products break down into microplastics, they become more dangerous than their original state, causing greater and more widespread harm to the ecological environment [31]. As their size decreases, microplastics can quickly bind with pollutants like heavy metals, organic substances, and microorganisms, facilitating the spread of these contaminants through the environment in different forms [29]. Microplastics are commonly found in marine ecosystems, making it easy for them to enter the human body through the seafood chain. Additionally, various food sources and everyday plastic food contact materials contain significant amounts of microplastics, indicating that human ingestion of microplastics is largely unavoidable [9,10]. Microplastics smaller than 20 μm can enter organs, while those smaller than 10 μm can pass through cell membranes and even cross the placental barrier in exposed cells or animals [32]. Therefore, as environmental microplastics degrade into smaller nanoplastics, there is an increased risk of penetrating organs, cell membranes, and tissues, allowing them to accumulate in organs and alter physiological processes [[33], [34], [35]]. Ingesting is the main pathway for microplastics, particularly nanoplastics, which can easily pass through cell membranes and the intestinal barrier into the bloodstream, subsequently relocating to other organs. Microplastics are also capable of penetrating the blood-brain barrier, accumulating in the brain, and exhibiting neurotoxicity [9]. Inhaled microplastics can cross the alveolar barrier and spread to organs via the bloodstream. Additionally, microplastics can be absorbed through skin contact with various topical agents [10]. Once in the bloodstream, microplastics can be redistributed to various organs. Microplastics have been found in a range of human tissue samples, such as feces, meconium, placenta, lung tissue samples, sputum, bronchoalveolar lavage fluid, breast milk, saliva, blood, face, liver, kidney, colon, and facial samples [10,36]. The exposure and accumulation of these microplastics can have harmful effects on multiple organs or organ systems [36], leading to tissue pathological changes and functional impairments in the digestive, respiratory, cardiovascular, immune, reproductive, and endocrine systems [37]. Moreover, microplastics exhibit transgenerational toxicity [38,39]. For instance, exposure to polystyrene microplastics (PS-MP) leads to induce physiological changes in Caenorhabditis elegans across subsequent generations [40]. Furthermore, microplastics have been demonstrated to transfer from mother to developing fetus in laboratory animals, as well as through analysis of human placentas. Maternal exposure to microplastics can alter offspring energy and lipid metabolism [10]. Some studies even indicate that maternal exposure to polystyrene nanoparticles (PS-NP) in mice results in abnormal brain development in offspring, increasing the risk of neurodevelopmental defects [41]. For humans, direct evidence linking microplastics to toxicity is still limited. In particular, there are no conclusive studies confirming the direct impact of microplastics or nanoplastics on diseases [37]. This lack of evidence may be attributed to the complexity of human metabolism and the possibility of low concentration exposure. Therefore, study on the potential negative effects of microplastics on organisms sometimes yields seemingly contradictory results. Recent research on the toxicity of microplastics to mammalian cells suggests that they may not be as damaging as initially thought, with effects typically occurring only at concentrations significantly higher than those found in the environment [15]. Additionally, over 90 % of ingested microplastics are excreted through feces [42]. On the other hand, the use of microplastics in the biomedical field appears beneficial. Due to their unique physicochemical properties of, nanoplastics have been actively and widely utilized as antigen carriers, imaging markers, and therapeutic drugs for disease diagnosis and treatment [43]. However, it is essential to recognize that microplastic pollution is characterized by low-dose, repetitive exposure. Over time, with the accumulation of microplastics in the body, there may be an increasing in high-burden microplastic cell populations, particularly in macrophages [19]. This review examines the toxic impact of microplastics on macrophages and the potential harmful consequences for various organ systems. Moreover, it explores strategies to target macrophages in order to prevent and mitigate the harm caused by microplastics.

sections.title: Macrophages: a critical barrier for defending against and internalizing microplastic particles
sections.text: Macrophages can be found in almost every tissue throughout the body [20]. They are known by different names depending on the tissue they inhabit, such as alveolar macrophages in the lungs, microglia in the nervous system, osteoclasts in bones, and Kupffer cells in the liver. These cells are crucial for the development of tissue and organ, injury repair, homeostasis, and the prevention of pathogens, chronic inflammation, fibrosis, and cancer [44]. Macrophages react to cues from their surroundings through polarization, making them crucial regulators and active participants in the immune system, providing timely immune responses. They can differentiate into various phenotypes and perform specific functions in diverse microenvironments [21]. Macrophages are essential in the gut barrier, lung air-blood barrier, and skin barrier, all of which are key entry points for microplastics into the human body. As the primary phagocytes in these mucosal environments and the most abundant cell type in the innate immune system, macrophages are vital for detecting and clearing pathogenic endogenous and exogenous chemicals across various tissues [45], acting as a key defense against microbes and environmental toxins [9,46]. Additionally, macrophages can act as carriers, transporting microplastic particles to different tissues [47]. Therefore, if these sentinel soldiers of immune defense fail, they could turn into a “Trojan horse”, inadvertently aiding in the breakdown of the body's defenses. Once microplastics enter the body, the organism first activates physical defenses, such as mucus secretion, followed by the recruitment of immune cells, particularly macrophages. A study on the distribution and bioaccumulation of nanoplastics found a significant presence of these particles within macrophages [48]. Macrophages are key players in the innate immune defense against foreign particles, being specifically responsible for their internalization. They can directly internalize microplastic particles up to 10 μm in diameter and are crucial for the cellular uptake of microplastics [19,49,50]. Research has investigated the cellular absorption and toxic effects of microplastics derived from synthetic polymers (including PS, PE, and PVC) as well as bio-derived polymers (such as PLA and cellulose acetate [CA]) within the size range of 1–4 μm on mouse macrophages and epithelial cells [51]. Despite variations in particle characteristics, such as ζ potential, surface morphology, and varying uptake rates [10], macrophages successfully internalize all the tested particles [51]. Although these findings support the notion that macrophages can uptake microplastics and that microplastics have certain toxic effects on macrophages, further research is needed to explore the relationship between cellular uptake and toxicity. It appears that the toxic effects of microplastics are related to subsequent accumulation. Studies indicate that macrophages internalize microplastics but do not degrade them [46]. Once internalized, these microplastics accumulate in lysosomes [10,45]. While microplastic particles can be passively released following macrophage death, no active excretion by live macrophages has been observed. Therefore, as long as the macrophages remain viable, the ingested particles persist, potentially leading to accumulation [49]. Accumulation of microplastics in lysosomes may result in lysosomal enzyme leakage and trigger inflammatory immune responses [45]. Furthermore, microplastics can cause lysosomal damage, prompting macrophage to reprogram and produce interleukin-1β (IL-1β) [7]. Research shows that microplastics from plastic food packaging (primarily PP and PET) are readily phagocytosed by alveolar macrophages, inducing inflammation and inhibiting lysosomal activity, thereby affecting the lysosomal digestion of autophagosomes and phagocytosed debris [52]. Macrophages have a dual function in the immune response, not only phagocytosing pathogens but also acting as immune effectors by presenting antigens and releasing both pro-inflammatory and anti-inflammatory cytokines [11]. Since antigen presentation and the secretion of inflammatory mediators by macrophages depend on the antigens they ingest, any impairment in their phagocytic function can compromise their overall immune effectiveness [53]. Continuous phagocytosis of indigestible microplastics can lead to rapid depletion of macrophages. The duration for the host to identify and clear these locally exhausted macrophages and replace them with new ones exceeds the normal duration needed for inflammation in response to pathogenic antigens, resulting in a temporary stagnation of host defense [54]. Furthermore, the inability of the immune system to clear microplastics may result in chronic inflammation and an increased risk of tumor development [55]. Additionally, the accumulation of microplastic particles within macrophages enhances their chemotactic migration, enabling these macrophages to enter the bloodstream and relocate to various macrophage-rich organs [19]. The presence of these high-load microplastic macrophage populations may have potentially harmful consequences for different organs and tissues throughout the body. Given that macrophages can undergo reversible phenotypic polarization in response to microenvironmental stimuli, transforming into either M1 macrophages that release pro-inflammatory cytokines or M2 macrophages that release anti-inflammatory cytokines [44], it is crucial to understand the toxic, metabolic, and functional effects of microplastics on macrophages (Fig. 2).Fig. 2Influence of ROS induced by microplastics on macrophage metabolism, function, and polarization. When macrophages ingest microplastics (MPs), the subsequent generation of reactive oxygen species (ROS) triggers a spectrum of cell death modalities, encompassing apoptosis, necrosis, ferroptosis, pyroptosis, and autophagic cell death. For example, MPs stimulate ROS production, leading to the upregulation of Bax, subsequently activates caspase 9 and caspase 3, thereby intensifying the apoptotic cascade. Additionally, MPs elevate mitochondrial ROS levels, which in turn activate necrosomes, initiating necrotic cell death. Moreover, MPs facilitate cell ferroptosis by augmenting ROS accumulation and lipid peroxidation. Simultaneously, NLRP3 becomes activated and engages with ASC, resulting in the proteolytic maturation of caspase-1. This matured caspase-1 then converts pro-IL-1β and pro-IL-18 into their active forms, IL-1 β and IL-18, respectively, thereby inducing pyroptosis. Furthermore, MP-induced ROS contribute to the formation of protein misfolding aggregates, inducing endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress. ROS also phosphorylates AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) and inhibits the AKT/mammalian target of rapamycin (mTOR) pathway, both actions reinforcing autophagic cell death. Notably, MP-triggered ROS initiates persistent mitophagy, causing lysosomal damage that liberates calcium ions. These calcium ions promote histone citrullination, thereby further inducing chromatin decondensation. sections.title: The effects of microplastics on macrophage viability, metabolism, and functional polarization
sections.text: The toxicity of microplastics is affected by particle size, concentration, and exposure duration [56,57]. Their toxic effects on macrophages also exhibit dependencies on these factors [11]. Smaller particles, higher concentrations, and longer exposure durations result in stronger cytotoxicity of microplastic particles [58]. Several in vivo and in vitro studies have demonstrated that upon exposure to PS-NPs, the cytotoxicity to macrophages increases as particle size decreases [20,59,60]. This indicates that particle size plays a crucial role in determining the toxic effects of microplastic particles on macrophages [61]. Additionally, macrophages absorb microplastics based on concentration, resulting in cytotoxic effects [11,62]. Studies have reported that macrophages exposed to PS-NPs at concentrations exceeding those currently found in human blood exhibit significantly increased necrosis [11,21]. Moreover, other studies have found that microplastics sized 0.5 mm are toxic to zebrafish macrophages at a concentration of 0.2 mg/mL, whereas 5 mm microplastics show toxicity at 0.5 mg/mL. These results highlight the significance of size and concentration as critical determinants of microplastic toxicity to macrophages [63]. However, some studies have reported contradictory results. For instance, a study involving mouse macrophages (J774A.1, ImKC) interacting with PS microplastic particles of varying sizes (0.2–6.0 μm) found that while macrophages actively phagocytosed microplastic particles of all sizes, no cytotoxic effects or impacts on cell proliferation were observed [64]. Similarly, another study that evaluated the cytotoxic effects of raw microplastic particles ranging from 1 to 4 μm, made from PS, PE, and PVC, as well as bio-derived polymer particles such as PLA and CA, concluded that these model polymer particles did not exhibit significant short-term cytotoxicity on mouse macrophages and epithelial cells [51]. These contradictory findings suggest that, in addition to concentration, size, and exposure duration, the pathophysiological effects of microplastics may also depend on factors such as polymer type, shape, environmental exposure, surface physicochemical properties, and interactions with surrounding proteins [10,47,58,[65], [66], [67]] (Table 1). Once ingested, microplastics can undergo extreme biochemical conditions in the gastrointestinal tract, resulting in the development of a unique protein corona on their surface. This protein corona, which is related to gastrointestinal digestion, may enhance the absorption by THP-1 derived human macrophages [68]. Furthermore, microplastic particles that have been environmentally exposed are more readily internalized by macrophages compared to raw microplastic particles. Research indicates that environmental exposure promotes the formation of an eco-corona of biomolecules on the surface of microplastic particles, facilitating their cellular internalization [47,50]. Additionally, the biological response of macrophages differs between aged and raw microplastics. Aged microplastics are more likely to cause greater cytotoxicity, heightened oxidative stress, and increased genotoxicity [49,65]. A study involving the mouse liver macrophage cell line ImKC exposed to either raw or weathered PS-MP demonstrated that although both types of microplastics were similarly absorbed by macrophages, only long-term weathered microplastics caused dose-dependent cytotoxic effects. In contrast, raw and briefly weathered microplastics primarily triggered inflammatory reactions based on concentration [15]. Moreover, the toxic effects of microplastics on macrophages vary with different surface functionalizations. In a PSNP study, RAW 264.7 mouse macrophages exhibited no cytotoxicity at 100 μg/mL after 24 h of treatment. However, surface functionalization with carboxyl (-COOH) and amino (-NH2) groups significantly enhanced cytotoxicity, causing significant cell death at concentrations of 20 μg/mL and 1 μg/mL, respectively [45]. Additionally, nanoplastics with a positive zeta potential tend to be more toxic than those with a negative zeta potential, likely because of their stronger interactions with the cell membrane [58]. These seemingly contradictory experimental results suggest that the uptake and toxicity of microplastics by macrophages must be understood in the context of the physicochemical properties and environmental conditions of the microplastics themselves, rather than being attributed to a single factor. One perspective suggests that cellular uptake may be higher in the absence of smaller protein particles [84]. Considering the relationship between cellular uptake and microenvironmental factors, future research should focus on how molecules in the microenvironment, such as metals and proteins, influence the uptake and effects of microplastics. Moreover, most studies on the cellular internalization of microplastics use fluorescently labeled particles, which can leach out or even exhibit toxicity themselves, potentially leading to significant errors in the results [11]. In conclusion, there is a pressing need for more comprehensive research on the toxicity variations of microplastics with different physicochemical properties or following environmental exposure. Additionally, more refined experimental techniques should be developed to investigate cytotoxic effects, enabling a better understanding of the toxic impacts of microplastics on macrophages. Microplastics can significantly alter the cellular metabolism of macrophages. Upon phagocytosis of microplastics, macrophages transition from a metabolically oxidative resting state to glycolysis, which is accompanied by a reduction in mitochondrial respiration. This metabolic shift is positively correlated with an increase in the expression of costimulatory molecules CD80 and CD86 on the cell surface, as well as the upregulation of pro-inflammatory cytokine genes [46]. In addition to altering metabolism, microplastics can activate and differentiate macrophages. They promote macrophage aggregation [85] and facilitate their maturation [12]. For instance, nanoplastics can penetrate bone marrow, impairing the migration capacity of pre-osteoblasts while enhancing osteoclastogenesis of pre-osteoclasts, thereby increasing the differentiation of RAW264.7 cells into osteoclasts at the morphological and molecular levels. Furthermore, microplastics induce polarization of macrophages towards the M1 phenotype. Studies have demonstrated that exposure to PS-M/NPs alters surface markers expression on mouse macrophages [19,46]. Specifically, microplastics enhance CD80 expression in RAW264.7 cells, indicating a transition to a pro-inflammatory phenotype [7]. Some studies have also reported a concentration-dependent effect, with lower concentrations of PS-NPs inducing a weaker pro-inflammatory response [86,87]. Gu et al. [88] observed that exposure to PS-M/NPs (100 nm, 5 μm, and 200 μm, 500 μg/L) led to an increase in the proportion of M1 macrophages and a decrease in M2 macrophages in the intestines of adult zebrafish. Additionally, research examining the long-term oral intake of microplastics in mice revealed increased macrophage infiltration in the liver, significantly raising the percentage of M1 macrophages while decreasing the proportion of M2 macrophages [89]. A recent study further demonstrated that PS-NPs promote M1 polarization of mouse RAW264.7 macrophages, regardless of size, identifying 50 μg/mL as a critical concentration threshold. Exceeding this concentration significantly affects macrophage activity, promoting M1 polarization while inhibiting M2 polarization [72]. Collectively, these findings indicate that microplastics can effectively induce a dominant M1 polarization state in macrophages. The inflammatory response is a critical mechanism underlying microplastic-induced cytotoxicity [37]. Macrophages, as key immune cells involved in inflammation, have been demonstrated in various in vitro and in vivo studies to exhibit pro-inflammatory responses upon exposure to microplastics. For example, Das et al. [10] showed that PS-NPs in the air can promote the release of inflammatory proteins like tumor necrosis factor- α (TNF-α), IL-6, and IL-1β in mouse alveolar macrophages. Similarly, other research indicated that 3 μm PS-MPs can stimulate TNF-α secretion and elevate its mRNA expression levels in RAW264.7 mouse macrophage cells [61]. Additionally, PS-NPs have been shown to activate Toll-like receptor 4 (TLR4)/p38-mediated pro-inflammatory pathways in mouse microglial cells (N9 cells) [90]. Moreover, various types of microplastic particles can also induce the production of inflammatory and oxidative stress markers in macrophages, such as monocyte chemoattractant protein-1 (MCP-1), macrophage inflammatory protein-2 (CXCL2), IL-6, and heme oxygenase-1 (HMOX-1) [59]. Specifically, polytetrafluoroethylene microplastics (PTFE-MPs) have been shown to increase the secretion of TNF-α and IL-6 in the U937 macrophage cell line [91]. Huang et al. [92] further found that PP-MPs at a concentration of 100 μg/mL can promote the release of TNF-α and IL-6 from mouse macrophages. While the degree of inflammation induced by microplastics varies depending on factors such as particle type, concentration, and duration of exposure, these findings collectively support the conclusion that microplastics promote M1 polarization of macrophages and exert pro-inflammatory effects. However, many studies have reported that microplastics may have no significant effect on the polarization and activation of macrophages. For instance, Adler et al. [11] reported that exposure to PS-NPs did not result in any changes in the surface marker expression of human macrophages. Similarly, Stock et al. [93] investigated the effects of microplastics ranging from 1 to 10 μm on macrophage polarization and activation using the human cell line THP-1. Although some microplastics were absorbed by the macrophages, in vivo data revealed no histologically detectable lesions or inflammatory responses. These findings suggest that microplastics do not impact the differentiation or functional activation of human macrophage models. Interestingly, there is evidence that microplastics may inhibit M1 polarization of macrophages or even promote M2 polarization. One study examining the effects of microplastics on phagocytic dendritic cells and macrophages in vitro showed a downregulation of pro-inflammatory M1 macrophage markers [20]. Additionally, other studies indicated that exposure to PS-MPs significantly shifted the M1/M2 macrophage ratio in mouse placenta towards the M2 subtype [94]. As previously mentioned, the absorption and toxic effects of microplastics are shaped by their physicochemical characteristics and environmental conditions. This implies that the influence of microplastics on M1 polarization and pro-inflammatory responses in macrophages may similarly be affected by these factors. The diverse surface physicochemical characteristics of microplastics can lead to either inflammatory or anti-inflammatory effects in macrophages. Research has shown that amino-functionalized polystyrene nanoparticles (PS–NH2) with diameters ranging from 1 to 100 nm, rather than carboxylated or non-functionalized particles, are capable of activating the NLRP3 inflammasome in human macrophages, promoting the release of IL-1β [95]. In contrast, another study found that carboxylated polystyrene particles measuring 500 nm and 1000 nm also triggered the release of pro-inflammatory cytokines, including IL-6 and IL-8, in monocytes and macrophages [87]. Notably, carboxylated PS-NPs demonstrated enhanced pro-inflammatory and cytotoxic effects [96]. Conversely, Fuchs et al. [97] observed that both carboxylated and amino-modified PS-NPs inhibited the polarization of macrophage to the M2 phenotype by reducing the levels of CD200R, CD163, and IL-10, without affecting M1 markers. This indicates that the effects of nanoparticles on the polarization of macrophage may depend both on the functional groups present and other physicochemical characteristics. Additionally, Huang's research group [98] found that hydrophilic polyurethane nanoparticles exhibit surface-dependent immunosuppressive properties, inhibiting M1 polarization of macrophages by decreasing TNF-α and IL-1β production. Furthermore, the surface charge of microplastics influences the formation of a protein corona, which plays a crucial role in macrophage polarization [99]. For microplastics exposed to environmental conditions and coated with an ecological corona, this effect may be further enhanced [11]. In conclusion, evaluating the effects of microplastics on macrophage polarization requires careful consideration of several factors. These include not only the variations in macrophage types used in experiments and potential experimental errors, but also the intrinsic characteristics of the microplastics themselves, such as size and surface physicochemical properties, as well as their exposure to environmental conditions. In addition to the direct toxicity of microplastic particles to cell membranes and organelles, as well as the adverse effects resulting from their accumulation in lysosomes [45,52,88,100], microplastics primarily induce cytotoxic endpoints, such as inflammation, genotoxicity, and apoptosis, in macrophages through the induction of oxidative stress [91,79,101]. Most studies indicate that the production of reactive oxygen species (ROS) and the resulting oxidative stress are closely related to the harmful effects of microplastics, serving as both initiating and key molecular events in microplastic-induced toxicity [[102], [103], [104]]. ROS are a group of highly reactive molecules formed as a result of cellular oxidative metabolism. They serve as signaling molecules in various biological processes and are also the end products of many metabolic reactions, including superoxide anion (O2•−), hydrogen peroxide (H2O2), and hydroxyl radicals (•OH) [105]. O2•− is a common precursor of all ROS produced by cells and can rapidly dismutate to H2O2 under the catalysis of superoxide dismutase (SOD) [106,107]. While ROS help cells carry out normal physiological activities, excessive ROS can disrupt redox balance, leading to adverse effects such as oxidative stress, protein oxidation, lipid peroxidation, DNA damage, and even cell death [10,100]. Key components of the antioxidant mechanisms that protect cells from ROS-induced stress include enzymes such as glutathione peroxidase (GPX), catalase (CAT), SOD, oxidized and reduced glutathione (GSSG/GSH), and glutathione reductase (GR). Once ROS are generated within the cell, an imbalance occurs if the antioxidant mechanisms cannot compensate for oxidative stress, leading to abnormal activation of cellular signaling pathways [10]. Microplastics can stimulate ROS production through oxidative bursts and activate various cytokines [58]. Even short-term exposure to microplastics can cause a rapid increase in intracellular ROS levels, leading to membrane damage and lipid peroxidation [108]. Furthermore, the accumulation of microplastics in organs can disrupt mitochondrial function, leading to uncontrolled ROS production and the initiation of inflammatory signaling cascades and various forms of cell death [10]. Several studies suggest that ROS-induced oxidative stress is a critical factor in the cytotoxicity associated with PS-NPs [109,110]. For macrophages, the two main endogenous sources of O2•− and H2O2 are the cytosolic NADPH oxidase (NOX) and mitochondria [[111], [112], [113]]. Following exposure to microplastics, macrophages rapidly internalize the ingested particles to facilitate their clearance. NOX and/or other enzymes generate O2•− and H2O2 [105,114], which subsequently accumulate in the mitochondria. In this context, microplastics compromise mitochondrial integrity, leading to an increased production of mitochondrial reactive oxygen species (mtROS) [115]. Both O2•− and H2O2 play roles in signal transduction and act as key mediators driving oxidative stress cascades [102]. Therefore, the ROS produced by macrophages not only play a critical role in antimicrobial defense but also regulate macrophage function by acting as important signaling molecules [116]. Microplastics can promote adverse outcomes in macrophages by enhancing ROS generation and altering metabolic characteristics [63,117,74]. Exposure to PS-NPs (500 μg/mL) induces oxidative stress in human macrophages and reduces cell proliferation [21]. PP particles smaller than 20 μm exhibit cytotoxicity to Raw 264.7 cells, with this toxicity being caused by increased ROS levels, occurring in a size- and concentration-dependent manner [118]. To further investigate the role of ROS in PS-NPs-induced necroptosis of macrophages, Fan et al. found that exposure to PS-NPs significantly downregulated the activity of the antioxidant SOD, total thiols (-SH), and GSH, while significantly upregulating the levels of the oxidative product malondialdehyde (MDA) in a dose-dependent manner. PS-NPs accumulate in the mitochondria of RAW 264.7 cells, and this accumulation leads to severe mitochondrial dysfunction, including the disturbance of complex I on the electron transport chain, membrane hyperpolarization, and ATP mutation, ultimately favoring the upregulation of mtROS to trigger necroptosis [115]. There is also evidence that ROS generated by PS-NH2 directly or indirectly affect the endoplasmic reticulum homeostasis and protein folding in macrophages, leading to endoplasmic reticulum stress and subsequent autophagic cell death [74]. PS-NPs may also induce microglial inflammatory responses and ferroptosis by promoting lipid peroxidation and ROS accumulation [119]. When exposed to NPs, the intracellular ROS levels in microglia significantly increase, while GSH and SOD levels decrease, and MDA levels rise. Pre-treatment with the ROS inhibitor N-acetylcysteine (NAC) significantly reduces the expression of MDA, while the activities of SOD and GSH are markedly increased. Furthermore, experimental results indicate that NP-induced inflammatory responses and ferroptosis are mediated by ROS. This suggests that ROS plays a critical role in the inflammation and ferroptosis of macrophages induced by microplastics [119]. Furthermore, the ROS produced by macrophages can coordinate immune responses through redox signaling in various ways, such as regulating the secretion of pro-inflammatory cytokines, activating inflammasomes, and coordinating subsequent adaptive immune responses through antigen presentation [[120], [121], [122]]. KC et al. [91] exposed six different human cell lines, including U937 and THP-1 macrophages, to two sizes of irregularly shaped PTFE-MPs with average diameters of 6.0 or 31.7 μm. They found that PTFE-MPs increased ROS levels across all tested cell lines, particularly in macrophages, and activated the ERK pathway, ultimately inducing oxidative stress and inflammation. Excessive ROS production is known to be a major contributor to the pathogenesis of inflammation and is associated with the progression of various inflammatory diseases [123]. Studies on nanoplastic-induced inflammation in macrophages have shown that nanoplastics can induce ROS production and activate the mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) and nuclear factor kappa B (NF-κB) pathways, leading to an upregulation of pro-inflammatory cytokines such as IL-6 and TNF-α [96]. Additionally, research has found that exposure to PS-NPs can lead to a decrease in mitochondrial membrane potential, accumulation of ROS, and calcium overload in RAW 264.7 cells. At elevated levels of ROS, this may result in mitochondrial dysfunction and the release of mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA). The free mtDNA within the cell can be recognized by cyclic GMP-AMP (cGAMP), activating the cGAS-STING signaling pathway associated with innate immunity [124]. Furthermore, PS-NPs can also induce the expression of downstream inflammatory factors, such as NF-κB, through the cGAS-STING pathway, leading to inflammation [125]. Jeon et al. [79] found a strong correlation between the intrinsic ROS-generating potential of microplastics and cytotoxic endpoints, including cytotoxicity and pro-inflammatory cytokines in THP-1 macrophages. However, some studies reported no increase in ROS production in macrophages after exposure to PS-NPs, which may be attributed to factors such as microplastic heterogeneity, concentration, exposure duration, and their effects on different tissue or cell types [11,104]. Among ROS, H2O2 is a promising candidate as a signaling messenger for cell death due to its relative stability, with a half-life of a few seconds. H2O2 easily penetrates cell membranes, allowing it to diffuse into neighboring cells and react with their components. The oxidants released by dying cells may kill adjacent cells through a bystander effect [126]. Thubagere et al. [127] found that nanoplastics can significantly impact cell viability in the CACO-2 intestinal membrane model by triggering apoptosis in individual cells, leading to oxidative stress that releases H2O2 into the extracellular environment and induces apoptosis in nearby cells. For macrophages, exposure to microplastics can generate substantial ROS, potentially affecting the function and health of surrounding cells through a similar bystander effect. While PS-NPs do not directly induce cytotoxicity in hepatocytes, they may upregulate ROS production and trigger redox-sensitive necroptosis in macrophages when co-cultured with RAW 264.7 cells, enhancing crosstalk between macrophages and hepatocytes and resulting in hepatocyte damage [115]. However, further evidence is needed to support the claim that microplastic exposure directly leads to increased ROS in the extracellular space of macrophages, making the exploration of microplastics’ impact on ROS levels in the macrophage microenvironment a promising direction for future research. ROS play a pivotal role in regulating intracellular redox signaling processes, particularly targeting redox-sensitive –SH. These –SH group, being highly reactive components within proteins, are susceptible to oxidation, leading to changes in protein structure and function. When macrophages exposed to MPs, studies have observed a decrease in –SH levels, which can be attributed to the oxidative stress induced by ROS [115]. Chiu et al. found that MP-induced ROS contribute to the formation of protein misfolding aggregates, and induce endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress. Additionally, ROS phosphorylate AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) and inhibit the AKT/mammalian target of rapamycin (mTOR) pathway. Both of these actions potentiate autophagic cell death [74]. During this process, ROS induce the oxidation of cysteine residues in AMPK, leading to further phosphorylation of active AMPK [128]. Furthermore, p62, a proteolytic autophagy receptor, is upregulated in response to MPs, particularly in response to H2O2. Under these conditions, p62 forms disulfide-linked conjugates, which contribute to the activation of autophagy [128]. The ingestion of MPs by macrophages leads to an overproduction of ROS, disrupting the cellular redox balance. In addition to ROS, nitric oxide (NO) is another important oxidative stress signaling molecule that plays a significant role in the inflammatory responses of macrophages. Following exposure to microplastics, increases in both ROS and NO levels in vivo and in vitro contribute to oxidative stress [91]. Research has found that PS-M/NPs stimulate NO production in mouse RAW264.7 cells in a dose-dependent manner by increasing the activity of nitric oxide synthase (NOS) [61]. NO reacts with superoxide to form peroxynitrite (ONOO−), a potent biological oxidant that affects mitochondrial function and triggers cell death through oxidative and nitrative reactions, potentially mediating severe bystander tissue damage [129]. The upregulation of NOS and accumulation of ROS induced by microplastics create the conditions for the generation of ONOO−. Under light irradiation, nitrogen-containing microplastics (N-MPs) will form persistent aminoxyl radicals (PAORs) and reactive nitrogen species (RNS). Nitric oxide radicals (•NO) generated by the photolysis of nitrone groups can react simultaneously with peroxyl radicals and superoxide anion radicals (O2•−), yielding nitrogen dioxide radicals (•NO2) and ONOO− respectively [130]. Pezzotti et al. [131] observed via specific nitrative stress-sensing dyes and high-resolution fluorescence microscopy that silicon nitride (Si3N4)-modified polymethylmethacrylate (PMMA) composites induce ONOO− radical accumulation in Candida albicans mitochondria, indicating that Si3N4-endowed PMMA surface chemistry mimics macrophage antifungal mechanisms, inducing NO and O2•− to react and form candidacidal ONOO−. Additionally, microplastic digestive clearance generates extensive RNS. Peng et al. [132] used near-infrared spectroscopy (NIR) to quantify Tenebrio molitor biodegradation kinetics of PS-MPs and found increased ONOO− levels during larval degradation of small (<30 μm) and large (<300 μm) PS-MPs, with larvae instinctively enhancing and heterogeneously redistributing intestinal ONOO− in response to MP biodegradation. The formation of ONOO− by macrophages represents a mechanism of cytotoxic effect that requires immune stimulation with cytokines that induce iNOS expression [133]. Additionally, exposure to nanoplastics has been shown to significantly increase the mRNA levels of iNOS in mouse microglia [90]. Taken together, these findings suggest that NO may serve as an additional mechanism through which microplastics exert pro-inflammatory effects on macrophages. It links the NOS-mediated generation of NO, the accumulation of ROS, and the ONOO−-related oxidative/nitrative stress. Besides the direct pathological and physiological effects of microplastics, it is important to highlight that many environmental microplastics contain additives. These additives can promote the adhesion and growth of bacterial pathogens on or within the particles, transforming microplastics into potential carriers of microbial toxicity. This raises concerns about the further toxic effects that may occur when these particles cross human biological barriers [1,18]. Microplastics can act as a Trojan horse for foreign pathogens, adversely affecting the resident microbiota of organisms and leading to dysbiosis in the gut, nose, and lungs [134,135]. For instance, Multiple studies have demonstrated that long-term exposure to microplastics in mice leads to dysbiosis, impaired intestinal barrier function, and metabolic disorders [18,136]. Environmental microplastics tend to enrich opportunistic pathogens decreasing the abundance of beneficial bacteria [137]. The relationship between gut probiotics and intestinal barrier integrity underscores that dysbiosis plays a significant indirect role in microplastic-induced intestinal dysfunction [138,139]. Furthermore, dysbiosis and intestinal dysfunction induced by microplastics can have widespread systemic effects on various host systems, including the digestive, immune, hematopoietic, nervous, and reproductive systems [18,[140], [141], [142], [143], [144]]. Studies have demonstrated that PS-MPs disrupt the gut microbiome, compromise the intestinal barrier, increase peripheral inflammation, and alter serum metabolites profiles. Additionally, Lipopolysaccharides (LPS) resulting from dysbiosis can activate macrophage TLR4, leading to the expression of hypoxia-inducible factor 1-alpha (HIF-1α). This activation initiates aerobic glycolysis, which enhances ATP production and promotes a pro-inflammatory phenotype in macrophages [145]. Importantly, research indicates that addressing the dysbiotic gut microbiome caused by PS-MPs can significantly reduce serum concentrations of LPS, IL-1β, IL-6, and TNF-α. This reduction may help prevent intestinal barrier damage and peripheral inflammation induced by PS-MPs. Furthermore, such interventions can inhibit the TLR4/MyD88/NF-κB pathway and thereby reducing neuroinflammation [137]. As previously mentioned, the innate immune system serves as the first line of defense against microbial and microplastic pollution, with macrophages playing a critical role in this response. Acting as gatekeepers, macrophages directly interact with microplastics, microorganisms, and their metabolic byproducts, effectively capturing and eliminating these “criminals” or “hit-and-run offenders”. Moreover, macrophages can mount an immune response to the metabolic products resulting from the interaction between microplastics and microorganisms. They adapt to changes in the microenvironment by expressing various functional programs tailored to the specific challenges they encounter. Therefore, long-term exposure to microplastics can lead to dysbiosis and metabolic disorders, which may adversely affect the functional activities of macrophages (Fig. 3). sections.title: The toxic effects of microplastics on macrophages due to their varying physicochemical properties and environmental exposure
sections.text: The toxicity of microplastics is affected by particle size, concentration, and exposure duration [56,57]. Their toxic effects on macrophages also exhibit dependencies on these factors [11]. Smaller particles, higher concentrations, and longer exposure durations result in stronger cytotoxicity of microplastic particles [58]. Several in vivo and in vitro studies have demonstrated that upon exposure to PS-NPs, the cytotoxicity to macrophages increases as particle size decreases [20,59,60]. This indicates that particle size plays a crucial role in determining the toxic effects of microplastic particles on macrophages [61]. Additionally, macrophages absorb microplastics based on concentration, resulting in cytotoxic effects [11,62]. Studies have reported that macrophages exposed to PS-NPs at concentrations exceeding those currently found in human blood exhibit significantly increased necrosis [11,21]. Moreover, other studies have found that microplastics sized 0.5 mm are toxic to zebrafish macrophages at a concentration of 0.2 mg/mL, whereas 5 mm microplastics show toxicity at 0.5 mg/mL. These results highlight the significance of size and concentration as critical determinants of microplastic toxicity to macrophages [63]. However, some studies have reported contradictory results. For instance, a study involving mouse macrophages (J774A.1, ImKC) interacting with PS microplastic particles of varying sizes (0.2–6.0 μm) found that while macrophages actively phagocytosed microplastic particles of all sizes, no cytotoxic effects or impacts on cell proliferation were observed [64]. Similarly, another study that evaluated the cytotoxic effects of raw microplastic particles ranging from 1 to 4 μm, made from PS, PE, and PVC, as well as bio-derived polymer particles such as PLA and CA, concluded that these model polymer particles did not exhibit significant short-term cytotoxicity on mouse macrophages and epithelial cells [51]. These contradictory findings suggest that, in addition to concentration, size, and exposure duration, the pathophysiological effects of microplastics may also depend on factors such as polymer type, shape, environmental exposure, surface physicochemical properties, and interactions with surrounding proteins [10,47,58,[65], [66], [67]] (Table 1). Once ingested, microplastics can undergo extreme biochemical conditions in the gastrointestinal tract, resulting in the development of a unique protein corona on their surface. This protein corona, which is related to gastrointestinal digestion, may enhance the absorption by THP-1 derived human macrophages [68]. Furthermore, microplastic particles that have been environmentally exposed are more readily internalized by macrophages compared to raw microplastic particles. Research indicates that environmental exposure promotes the formation of an eco-corona of biomolecules on the surface of microplastic particles, facilitating their cellular internalization [47,50]. Additionally, the biological response of macrophages differs between aged and raw microplastics. Aged microplastics are more likely to cause greater cytotoxicity, heightened oxidative stress, and increased genotoxicity [49,65]. A study involving the mouse liver macrophage cell line ImKC exposed to either raw or weathered PS-MP demonstrated that although both types of microplastics were similarly absorbed by macrophages, only long-term weathered microplastics caused dose-dependent cytotoxic effects. In contrast, raw and briefly weathered microplastics primarily triggered inflammatory reactions based on concentration [15]. Moreover, the toxic effects of microplastics on macrophages vary with different surface functionalizations. In a PSNP study, RAW 264.7 mouse macrophages exhibited no cytotoxicity at 100 μg/mL after 24 h of treatment. However, surface functionalization with carboxyl (-COOH) and amino (-NH2) groups significantly enhanced cytotoxicity, causing significant cell death at concentrations of 20 μg/mL and 1 μg/mL, respectively [45]. Additionally, nanoplastics with a positive zeta potential tend to be more toxic than those with a negative zeta potential, likely because of their stronger interactions with the cell membrane [58]. One perspective suggests that cellular uptake may be higher in the absence of smaller protein particles [84]. Considering the relationship between cellular uptake and microenvironmental factors, future research should focus on how molecules in the microenvironment, such as metals and proteins, influence the uptake and effects of microplastics. Moreover, most studies on the cellular internalization of microplastics use fluorescently labeled particles, which can leach out or even exhibit toxicity themselves, potentially leading to significant errors in the results [11]. In conclusion, there is a pressing need for more comprehensive research on the toxicity variations of microplastics with different physicochemical properties or following environmental exposure. Additionally, more refined experimental techniques should be developed to investigate cytotoxic effects, enabling a better understanding of the toxic impacts of microplastics on macrophages.

sections.title: The effects of microplastics on macrophage metabolism and polarization
sections.text: Microplastics can significantly alter the cellular metabolism of macrophages. Upon phagocytosis of microplastics, macrophages transition from a metabolically oxidative resting state to glycolysis, which is accompanied by a reduction in mitochondrial respiration. This metabolic shift is positively correlated with an increase in the expression of costimulatory molecules CD80 and CD86 on the cell surface, as well as the upregulation of pro-inflammatory cytokine genes [46]. In addition to altering metabolism, microplastics can activate and differentiate macrophages. They promote macrophage aggregation [85] and facilitate their maturation [12]. For instance, nanoplastics can penetrate bone marrow, impairing the migration capacity of pre-osteoblasts while enhancing osteoclastogenesis of pre-osteoclasts, thereby increasing the differentiation of RAW264.7 cells into osteoclasts at the morphological and molecular levels. Furthermore, microplastics induce polarization of macrophages towards the M1 phenotype. Studies have demonstrated that exposure to PS-M/NPs alters surface markers expression on mouse macrophages [19,46]. Specifically, microplastics enhance CD80 expression in RAW264.7 cells, indicating a transition to a pro-inflammatory phenotype [7]. Some studies have also reported a concentration-dependent effect, with lower concentrations of PS-NPs inducing a weaker pro-inflammatory response [86,87]. Gu et al. [88] observed that exposure to PS-M/NPs (100 nm, 5 μm, and 200 μm, 500 μg/L) led to an increase in the proportion of M1 macrophages and a decrease in M2 macrophages in the intestines of adult zebrafish. Additionally, research examining the long-term oral intake of microplastics in mice revealed increased macrophage infiltration in the liver, significantly raising the percentage of M1 macrophages while decreasing the proportion of M2 macrophages [89]. A recent study further demonstrated that PS-NPs promote M1 polarization of mouse RAW264.7 macrophages, regardless of size, identifying 50 μg/mL as a critical concentration threshold. Exceeding this concentration significantly affects macrophage activity, promoting M1 polarization while inhibiting M2 polarization [72]. Collectively, these findings indicate that microplastics can effectively induce a dominant M1 polarization state in macrophages. The inflammatory response is a critical mechanism underlying microplastic-induced cytotoxicity [37]. Macrophages, as key immune cells involved in inflammation, have been demonstrated in various in vitro and in vivo studies to exhibit pro-inflammatory responses upon exposure to microplastics. For example, Das et al. [10] showed that PS-NPs in the air can promote the release of inflammatory proteins like tumor necrosis factor- α (TNF-α), IL-6, and IL-1β in mouse alveolar macrophages. Similarly, other research indicated that 3 μm PS-MPs can stimulate TNF-α secretion and elevate its mRNA expression levels in RAW264.7 mouse macrophage cells [61]. Additionally, PS-NPs have been shown to activate Toll-like receptor 4 (TLR4)/p38-mediated pro-inflammatory pathways in mouse microglial cells (N9 cells) [90]. Moreover, various types of microplastic particles can also induce the production of inflammatory and oxidative stress markers in macrophages, such as monocyte chemoattractant protein-1 (MCP-1), macrophage inflammatory protein-2 (CXCL2), IL-6, and heme oxygenase-1 (HMOX-1) [59]. Specifically, polytetrafluoroethylene microplastics (PTFE-MPs) have been shown to increase the secretion of TNF-α and IL-6 in the U937 macrophage cell line [91]. Huang et al. [92] further found that PP-MPs at a concentration of 100 μg/mL can promote the release of TNF-α and IL-6 from mouse macrophages. While the degree of inflammation induced by microplastics varies depending on factors such as particle type, concentration, and duration of exposure, these findings collectively support the conclusion that microplastics promote M1 polarization of macrophages and exert pro-inflammatory effects.
