These seemingly contradictory experimental results suggest that the uptake and toxicity of microplastics by macrophages must be understood in the context of the physicochemical properties and environmental conditions of the microplastics themselves, rather than being attributed to a single factor. One perspective suggests that cellular uptake may be higher in the absence of smaller protein particles [84]. Considering the relationship between cellular uptake and microenvironmental factors, future research should focus on how molecules in the microenvironment, such as metals and proteins, influence the uptake and effects of microplastics. Moreover, most studies on the cellular internalization of microplastics use fluorescently labeled particles, which can leach out or even exhibit toxicity themselves, potentially leading to significant errors in the results [11]. In conclusion, there is a pressing need for more comprehensive research on the toxicity variations of microplastics with different physicochemical properties or following environmental exposure. Additionally, more refined experimental techniques should be developed to investigate cytotoxic effects, enabling a better understanding of the toxic impacts of microplastics on macrophages. Microplastics can significantly alter the cellular metabolism of macrophages. Upon phagocytosis of microplastics, macrophages transition from a metabolically oxidative resting state to glycolysis, which is accompanied by a reduction in mitochondrial respiration. This metabolic shift is positively correlated with an increase in the expression of costimulatory molecules CD80 and CD86 on the cell surface, as well as the upregulation of pro-inflammatory cytokine genes [46]. In addition to altering metabolism, microplastics can activate and differentiate macrophages. They promote macrophage aggregation [85] and facilitate their maturation [12]. For instance, nanoplastics can penetrate bone marrow, impairing the migration capacity of pre-osteoblasts while enhancing osteoclastogenesis of pre-osteoclasts, thereby increasing the differentiation of RAW264.7 cells into osteoclasts at the morphological and molecular levels. Furthermore, microplastics induce polarization of macrophages towards the M1 phenotype. Studies have demonstrated that exposure to PS-M/NPs alters surface markers expression on mouse macrophages [19,46]. Specifically, microplastics enhance CD80 expression in RAW264.7 cells, indicating a transition to a pro-inflammatory phenotype [7]. Some studies have also reported a concentration-dependent effect, with lower concentrations of PS-NPs inducing a weaker pro-inflammatory response [86,87]. Gu et al. [88] observed that exposure to PS-M/NPs (100 nm, 5 μm, and 200 μm, 500 μg/L) led to an increase in the proportion of M1 macrophages and a decrease in M2 macrophages in the intestines of adult zebrafish. Additionally, research examining the long-term oral intake of microplastics in mice revealed increased macrophage infiltration in the liver, significantly raising the percentage of M1 macrophages while decreasing the proportion of M2 macrophages [89]. A recent study further demonstrated that PS-NPs promote M1 polarization of mouse RAW264.7 macrophages, regardless of size, identifying 50 μg/mL as a critical concentration threshold. Exceeding this concentration significantly affects macrophage activity, promoting M1 polarization while inhibiting M2 polarization [72]. Collectively, these findings indicate that microplastics can effectively induce a dominant M1 polarization state in macrophages. The inflammatory response is a critical mechanism underlying microplastic-induced cytotoxicity [37]. Macrophages, as key immune cells involved in inflammation, have been demonstrated in various in vitro and in vivo studies to exhibit pro-inflammatory responses upon exposure to microplastics. For example, Das et al. [10] showed that PS-NPs in the air can promote the release of inflammatory proteins like tumor necrosis factor- α (TNF-α), IL-6, and IL-1β in mouse alveolar macrophages. Similarly, other research indicated that 3 μm PS-MPs can stimulate TNF-α secretion and elevate its mRNA expression levels in RAW264.7 mouse macrophage cells [61]. Additionally, PS-NPs have been shown to activate Toll-like receptor 4 (TLR4)/p38-mediated pro-inflammatory pathways in mouse microglial cells (N9 cells) [90]. Moreover, various types of microplastic particles can also induce the production of inflammatory and oxidative stress markers in macrophages, such as monocyte chemoattractant protein-1 (MCP-1), macrophage inflammatory protein-2 (CXCL2), IL-6, and heme oxygenase-1 (HMOX-1) [59]. Specifically, polytetrafluoroethylene microplastics (PTFE-MPs) have been shown to increase the secretion of TNF-α and IL-6 in the U937 macrophage cell line [91]. Huang et al. [92] further found that PP-MPs at a concentration of 100 μg/mL can promote the release of TNF-α and IL-6 from mouse macrophages. While the degree of inflammation induced by microplastics varies depending on factors such as particle type, concentration, and duration of exposure, these findings collectively support the conclusion that microplastics promote M1 polarization of macrophages and exert pro-inflammatory effects. However, many studies have reported that microplastics may have no significant effect on the polarization and activation of macrophages. For instance, Adler et al. [11] reported that exposure to PS-NPs did not result in any changes in the surface marker expression of human macrophages. Similarly, Stock et al. [93] investigated the effects of microplastics ranging from 1 to 10 μm on macrophage polarization and activation using the human cell line THP-1. Although some microplastics were absorbed by the macrophages, in vivo data revealed no histologically detectable lesions or inflammatory responses. These findings suggest that microplastics do not impact the differentiation or functional activation of human macrophage models. Interestingly, there is evidence that microplastics may inhibit M1 polarization of macrophages or even promote M2 polarization. One study examining the effects of microplastics on phagocytic dendritic cells and macrophages in vitro showed a downregulation of pro-inflammatory M1 macrophage markers [20]. Additionally, other studies indicated that exposure to PS-MPs significantly shifted the M1/M2 macrophage ratio in mouse placenta towards the M2 subtype [94]. As previously mentioned, the absorption and toxic effects of microplastics are shaped by their physicochemical characteristics and environmental conditions. This implies that the influence of microplastics on M1 polarization and pro-inflammatory responses in macrophages may similarly be affected by these factors. The diverse surface physicochemical characteristics of microplastics can lead to either inflammatory or anti-inflammatory effects in macrophages. Research has shown that amino-functionalized polystyrene nanoparticles (PS–NH2) with diameters ranging from 1 to 100 nm, rather than carboxylated or non-functionalized particles, are capable of activating the NLRP3 inflammasome in human macrophages, promoting the release of IL-1β [95]. In contrast, another study found that carboxylated polystyrene particles measuring 500 nm and 1000 nm also triggered the release of pro-inflammatory cytokines, including IL-6 and IL-8, in monocytes and macrophages [87]. Notably, carboxylated PS-NPs demonstrated enhanced pro-inflammatory and cytotoxic effects [96]. Conversely, Fuchs et al. [97] observed that both carboxylated and amino-modified PS-NPs inhibited the polarization of macrophage to the M2 phenotype by reducing the levels of CD200R, CD163, and IL-10, without affecting M1 markers. This indicates that the effects of nanoparticles on the polarization of macrophage may depend both on the functional groups present and other physicochemical characteristics. Additionally, Huang's research group [98] found that hydrophilic polyurethane nanoparticles exhibit surface-dependent immunosuppressive properties, inhibiting M1 polarization of macrophages by decreasing TNF-α and IL-1β production. Furthermore, the surface charge of microplastics influences the formation of a protein corona, which plays a crucial role in macrophage polarization [99]. For microplastics exposed to environmental conditions and coated with an ecological corona, this effect may be further enhanced [11]. In conclusion, evaluating the effects of microplastics on macrophage polarization requires careful consideration of several factors. These include not only the variations in macrophage types used in experiments and potential experimental errors, but also the intrinsic characteristics of the microplastics themselves, such as size and surface physicochemical properties, as well as their exposure to environmental conditions. In addition to the direct toxicity of microplastic particles to cell membranes and organelles, as well as the adverse effects resulting from their accumulation in lysosomes [45,52,88,100], microplastics primarily induce cytotoxic endpoints, such as inflammation, genotoxicity, and apoptosis, in macrophages through the induction of oxidative stress [91,79,101]. Most studies indicate that the production of reactive oxygen species (ROS) and the resulting oxidative stress are closely related to the harmful effects of microplastics, serving as both initiating and key molecular events in microplastic-induced toxicity [[102], [103], [104]]. ROS are a group of highly reactive molecules formed as a result of cellular oxidative metabolism. They serve as signaling molecules in various biological processes and are also the end products of many metabolic reactions, including superoxide anion (O2•−), hydrogen peroxide (H2O2), and hydroxyl radicals (•OH) [105]. O2•− is a common precursor of all ROS produced by cells and can rapidly dismutate to H2O2 under the catalysis of superoxide dismutase (SOD) [106,107]. While ROS help cells carry out normal physiological activities, excessive ROS can disrupt redox balance, leading to adverse effects such as oxidative stress, protein oxidation, lipid peroxidation, DNA damage, and even cell death [10,100]. Key components of the antioxidant mechanisms that protect cells from ROS-induced stress include enzymes such as glutathione peroxidase (GPX), catalase (CAT), SOD, oxidized and reduced glutathione (GSSG/GSH), and glutathione reductase (GR). Once ROS are generated within the cell, an imbalance occurs if the antioxidant mechanisms cannot compensate for oxidative stress, leading to abnormal activation of cellular signaling pathways [10]. Microplastics can stimulate ROS production through oxidative bursts and activate various cytokines [58]. Even short-term exposure to microplastics can cause a rapid increase in intracellular ROS levels, leading to membrane damage and lipid peroxidation [108]. Furthermore, the accumulation of microplastics in organs can disrupt mitochondrial function, leading to uncontrolled ROS production and the initiation of inflammatory signaling cascades and various forms of cell death [10]. Several studies suggest that ROS-induced oxidative stress is a critical factor in the cytotoxicity associated with PS-NPs [109,110]. For macrophages, the two main endogenous sources of O2•− and H2O2 are the cytosolic NADPH oxidase (NOX) and mitochondria [[111], [112], [113]]. Following exposure to microplastics, macrophages rapidly internalize the ingested particles to facilitate their clearance. NOX and/or other enzymes generate O2•− and H2O2 [105,114], which subsequently accumulate in the mitochondria. In this context, microplastics compromise mitochondrial integrity, leading to an increased production of mitochondrial reactive oxygen species (mtROS) [115]. Both O2•− and H2O2 play roles in signal transduction and act as key mediators driving oxidative stress cascades [102]. Therefore, the ROS produced by macrophages not only play a critical role in antimicrobial defense but also regulate macrophage function by acting as important signaling molecules [116]. Microplastics can promote adverse outcomes in macrophages by enhancing ROS generation and altering metabolic characteristics [63,117,74]. Exposure to PS-NPs (500 μg/mL) induces oxidative stress in human macrophages and reduces cell proliferation [21]. PP particles smaller than 20 μm exhibit cytotoxicity to Raw 264.7 cells, with this toxicity being caused by increased ROS levels, occurring in a size- and concentration-dependent manner [118]. To further investigate the role of ROS in PS-NPs-induced necroptosis of macrophages, Fan et al. found that exposure to PS-NPs significantly downregulated the activity of the antioxidant SOD, total thiols (-SH), and GSH, while significantly upregulating the levels of the oxidative product malondialdehyde (MDA) in a dose-dependent manner. PS-NPs accumulate in the mitochondria of RAW 264.7 cells, and this accumulation leads to severe mitochondrial dysfunction, including the disturbance of complex I on the electron transport chain, membrane hyperpolarization, and ATP mutation, ultimately favoring the upregulation of mtROS to trigger necroptosis [115]. There is also evidence that ROS generated by PS-NH2 directly or indirectly affect the endoplasmic reticulum homeostasis and protein folding in macrophages, leading to endoplasmic reticulum stress and subsequent autophagic cell death [74]. PS-NPs may also induce microglial inflammatory responses and ferroptosis by promoting lipid peroxidation and ROS accumulation [119]. When exposed to NPs, the intracellular ROS levels in microglia significantly increase, while GSH and SOD levels decrease, and MDA levels rise. Pre-treatment with the ROS inhibitor N-acetylcysteine (NAC) significantly reduces the expression of MDA, while the activities of SOD and GSH are markedly increased. Furthermore, experimental results indicate that NP-induced inflammatory responses and ferroptosis are mediated by ROS. This suggests that ROS plays a critical role in the inflammation and ferroptosis of macrophages induced by microplastics [119]. Furthermore, the ROS produced by macrophages can coordinate immune responses through redox signaling in various ways, such as regulating the secretion of pro-inflammatory cytokines, activating inflammasomes, and coordinating subsequent adaptive immune responses through antigen presentation [[120], [121], [122]]. KC et al. [91] exposed six different human cell lines, including U937 and THP-1 macrophages, to two sizes of irregularly shaped PTFE-MPs with average diameters of 6.0 or 31.7 μm. They found that PTFE-MPs increased ROS levels across all tested cell lines, particularly in macrophages, and activated the ERK pathway, ultimately inducing oxidative stress and inflammation. Excessive ROS production is known to be a major contributor to the pathogenesis of inflammation and is associated with the progression of various inflammatory diseases [123]. Studies on nanoplastic-induced inflammation in macrophages have shown that nanoplastics can induce ROS production and activate the mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) and nuclear factor kappa B (NF-κB) pathways, leading to an upregulation of pro-inflammatory cytokines such as IL-6 and TNF-α [96]. Additionally, research has found that exposure to PS-NPs can lead to a decrease in mitochondrial membrane potential, accumulation of ROS, and calcium overload in RAW 264.7 cells. At elevated levels of ROS, this may result in mitochondrial dysfunction and the release of mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA). The free mtDNA within the cell can be recognized by cyclic GMP-AMP (cGAMP), activating the cGAS-STING signaling pathway associated with innate immunity [124]. Furthermore, PS-NPs can also induce the expression of downstream inflammatory factors, such as NF-κB, through the cGAS-STING pathway, leading to inflammation [125]. Jeon et al. [79] found a strong correlation between the intrinsic ROS-generating potential of microplastics and cytotoxic endpoints, including cytotoxicity and pro-inflammatory cytokines in THP-1 macrophages. However, some studies reported no increase in ROS production in macrophages after exposure to PS-NPs, which may be attributed to factors such as microplastic heterogeneity, concentration, exposure duration, and their effects on different tissue or cell types [11,104]. Among ROS, H2O2 is a promising candidate as a signaling messenger for cell death due to its relative stability, with a half-life of a few seconds. H2O2 easily penetrates cell membranes, allowing it to diffuse into neighboring cells and react with their components. The oxidants released by dying cells may kill adjacent cells through a bystander effect [126]. Thubagere et al. [127] found that nanoplastics can significantly impact cell viability in the CACO-2 intestinal membrane model by triggering apoptosis in individual cells, leading to oxidative stress that releases H2O2 into the extracellular environment and induces apoptosis in nearby cells. For macrophages, exposure to microplastics can generate substantial ROS, potentially affecting the function and health of surrounding cells through a similar bystander effect. While PS-NPs do not directly induce cytotoxicity in hepatocytes, they may upregulate ROS production and trigger redox-sensitive necroptosis in macrophages when co-cultured with RAW 264.7 cells, enhancing crosstalk between macrophages and hepatocytes and resulting in hepatocyte damage [115]. However, further evidence is needed to support the claim that microplastic exposure directly leads to increased ROS in the extracellular space of macrophages, making the exploration of microplastics’ impact on ROS levels in the macrophage microenvironment a promising direction for future research. ROS play a pivotal role in regulating intracellular redox signaling processes, particularly targeting redox-sensitive –SH. These –SH group, being highly reactive components within proteins, are susceptible to oxidation, leading to changes in protein structure and function. When macrophages exposed to MPs, studies have observed a decrease in –SH levels, which can be attributed to the oxidative stress induced by ROS [115]. Chiu et al. found that MP-induced ROS contribute to the formation of protein misfolding aggregates, and induce endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress. Additionally, ROS phosphorylate AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) and inhibit the AKT/mammalian target of rapamycin (mTOR) pathway. Both of these actions potentiate autophagic cell death [74]. During this process, ROS induce the oxidation of cysteine residues in AMPK, leading to further phosphorylation of active AMPK [128]. Furthermore, p62, a proteolytic autophagy receptor, is upregulated in response to MPs, particularly in response to H2O2. Under these conditions, p62 forms disulfide-linked conjugates, which contribute to the activation of autophagy [128]. The ingestion of MPs by macrophages leads to an overproduction of ROS, disrupting the cellular redox balance. In addition to ROS, nitric oxide (NO) is another important oxidative stress signaling molecule that plays a significant role in the inflammatory responses of macrophages. Following exposure to microplastics, increases in both ROS and NO levels in vivo and in vitro contribute to oxidative stress [91]. Research has found that PS-M/NPs stimulate NO production in mouse RAW264.7 cells in a dose-dependent manner by increasing the activity of nitric oxide synthase (NOS) [61]. NO reacts with superoxide to form peroxynitrite (ONOO−), a potent biological oxidant that affects mitochondrial function and triggers cell death through oxidative and nitrative reactions, potentially mediating severe bystander tissue damage [129]. The upregulation of NOS and accumulation of ROS induced by microplastics create the conditions for the generation of ONOO−. Under light irradiation, nitrogen-containing microplastics (N-MPs) will form persistent aminoxyl radicals (PAORs) and reactive nitrogen species (RNS). Nitric oxide radicals (•NO) generated by the photolysis of nitrone groups can react simultaneously with peroxyl radicals and superoxide anion radicals (O2•−), yielding nitrogen dioxide radicals (•NO2) and ONOO− respectively [130]. Pezzotti et al. [131] observed via specific nitrative stress-sensing dyes and high-resolution fluorescence microscopy that silicon nitride (Si3N4)-modified polymethylmethacrylate (PMMA) composites induce ONOO− radical accumulation in Candida albicans mitochondria, indicating that Si3N4-endowed PMMA surface chemistry mimics macrophage antifungal mechanisms, inducing NO and O2•− to react and form candidacidal ONOO−. Additionally, microplastic digestive clearance generates extensive RNS. Peng et al. [132] used near-infrared spectroscopy (NIR) to quantify Tenebrio molitor biodegradation kinetics of PS-MPs and found increased ONOO− levels during larval degradation of small (<30 μm) and large (<300 μm) PS-MPs, with larvae instinctively enhancing and heterogeneously redistributing intestinal ONOO− in response to MP biodegradation. The formation of ONOO− by macrophages represents a mechanism of cytotoxic effect that requires immune stimulation with cytokines that induce iNOS expression [133]. Additionally, exposure to nanoplastics has been shown to significantly increase the mRNA levels of iNOS in mouse microglia [90]. Taken together, these findings suggest that NO may serve as an additional mechanism through which microplastics exert pro-inflammatory effects on macrophages. It links the NOS-mediated generation of NO, the accumulation of ROS, and the ONOO−-related oxidative/nitrative stress. Besides the direct pathological and physiological effects of microplastics, it is important to highlight that many environmental microplastics contain additives. These additives can promote the adhesion and growth of bacterial pathogens on or within the particles, transforming microplastics into potential carriers of microbial toxicity. This raises concerns about the further toxic effects that may occur when these particles cross human biological barriers [1,18]. Microplastics can act as a Trojan horse for foreign pathogens, adversely affecting the resident microbiota of organisms and leading to dysbiosis in the gut, nose, and lungs [134,135]. For instance, Multiple studies have demonstrated that long-term exposure to microplastics in mice leads to dysbiosis, impaired intestinal barrier function, and metabolic disorders [18,136]. Environmental microplastics tend to enrich opportunistic pathogens decreasing the abundance of beneficial bacteria [137]. The relationship between gut probiotics and intestinal barrier integrity underscores that dysbiosis plays a significant indirect role in microplastic-induced intestinal dysfunction [138,139]. Furthermore, dysbiosis and intestinal dysfunction induced by microplastics can have widespread systemic effects on various host systems, including the digestive, immune, hematopoietic, nervous, and reproductive systems [18,[140], [141], [142], [143], [144]]. Studies have demonstrated that PS-MPs disrupt the gut microbiome, compromise the intestinal barrier, increase peripheral inflammation, and alter serum metabolites profiles. Additionally, Lipopolysaccharides (LPS) resulting from dysbiosis can activate macrophage TLR4, leading to the expression of hypoxia-inducible factor 1-alpha (HIF-1α). This activation initiates aerobic glycolysis, which enhances ATP production and promotes a pro-inflammatory phenotype in macrophages [145]. Importantly, research indicates that addressing the dysbiotic gut microbiome caused by PS-MPs can significantly reduce serum concentrations of LPS, IL-1β, IL-6, and TNF-α. This reduction may help prevent intestinal barrier damage and peripheral inflammation induced by PS-MPs. Furthermore, such interventions can inhibit the TLR4/MyD88/NF-κB pathway and thereby reducing neuroinflammation [137]. As previously mentioned, the innate immune system serves as the first line of defense against microbial and microplastic pollution, with macrophages playing a critical role in this response. Acting as gatekeepers, macrophages directly interact with microplastics, microorganisms, and their metabolic byproducts, effectively capturing and eliminating these “criminals” or “hit-and-run offenders”. Moreover, macrophages can mount an immune response to the metabolic products resulting from the interaction between microplastics and microorganisms. They adapt to changes in the microenvironment by expressing various functional programs tailored to the specific challenges they encounter. Therefore, long-term exposure to microplastics can lead to dysbiosis and metabolic disorders, which may adversely affect the functional activities of macrophages (Fig. 3). ## The toxic effects of microplastics on macrophages due to their varying physicochemical properties and environmental exposure
The toxicity of microplastics is affected by particle size, concentration, and exposure duration [56,57]. Their toxic effects on macrophages also exhibit dependencies on these factors [11]. Smaller particles, higher concentrations, and longer exposure durations result in stronger cytotoxicity of microplastic particles [58]. Several in vivo and in vitro studies have demonstrated that upon exposure to PS-NPs, the cytotoxicity to macrophages increases as particle size decreases [20,59,60]. This indicates that particle size plays a crucial role in determining the toxic effects of microplastic particles on macrophages [61]. Additionally, macrophages absorb microplastics based on concentration, resulting in cytotoxic effects [11,62]. Studies have reported that macrophages exposed to PS-NPs at concentrations exceeding those currently found in human blood exhibit significantly increased necrosis [11,21]. Moreover, other studies have found that microplastics sized 0.5 mm are toxic to zebrafish macrophages at a concentration of 0.2 mg/mL, whereas 5 mm microplastics show toxicity at 0.5 mg/mL. These results highlight the significance of size and concentration as critical determinants of microplastic toxicity to macrophages [63]. However, some studies have reported contradictory results. For instance, a study involving mouse macrophages (J774A.1, ImKC) interacting with PS microplastic particles of varying sizes (0.2–6.0 μm) found that while macrophages actively phagocytosed microplastic particles of all sizes, no cytotoxic effects or impacts on cell proliferation were observed [64]. Similarly, another study that evaluated the cytotoxic effects of raw microplastic particles ranging from 1 to 4 μm, made from PS, PE, and PVC, as well as bio-derived polymer particles such as PLA and CA, concluded that these model polymer particles did not exhibit significant short-term cytotoxicity on mouse macrophages and epithelial cells [51]. These contradictory findings suggest that, in addition to concentration, size, and exposure duration, the pathophysiological effects of microplastics may also depend on factors such as polymer type, shape, environmental exposure, surface physicochemical properties, and interactions with surrounding proteins [10,47,58,[65], [66], [67]] (Table 1). Once ingested, microplastics can undergo extreme biochemical conditions in the gastrointestinal tract, resulting in the development of a unique protein corona on their surface. This protein corona, which is related to gastrointestinal digestion, may enhance the absorption by THP-1 derived human macrophages [68]. Furthermore, microplastic particles that have been environmentally exposed are more readily internalized by macrophages compared to raw microplastic particles. Research indicates that environmental exposure promotes the formation of an eco-corona of biomolecules on the surface of microplastic particles, facilitating their cellular internalization [47,50]. Additionally, the biological response of macrophages differs between aged and raw microplastics. Aged microplastics are more likely to cause greater cytotoxicity, heightened oxidative stress, and increased genotoxicity [49,65]. A study involving the mouse liver macrophage cell line ImKC exposed to either raw or weathered PS-MP demonstrated that although both types of microplastics were similarly absorbed by macrophages, only long-term weathered microplastics caused dose-dependent cytotoxic effects. In contrast, raw and briefly weathered microplastics primarily triggered inflammatory reactions based on concentration [15]. Moreover, the toxic effects of microplastics on macrophages vary with different surface functionalizations. In a PSNP study, RAW 264.7 mouse macrophages exhibited no cytotoxicity at 100 μg/mL after 24 h of treatment. However, surface functionalization with carboxyl (-COOH) and amino (-NH2) groups significantly enhanced cytotoxicity, causing significant cell death at concentrations of 20 μg/mL and 1 μg/mL, respectively [45]. Additionally, nanoplastics with a positive zeta potential tend to be more toxic than those with a negative zeta potential, likely because of their stronger interactions with the cell membrane [58]. ## The effects of microplastics on macrophage metabolism and polarization
Microplastics can significantly alter the cellular metabolism of macrophages. Upon phagocytosis of microplastics, macrophages transition from a metabolically oxidative resting state to glycolysis, which is accompanied by a reduction in mitochondrial respiration. This metabolic shift is positively correlated with an increase in the expression of costimulatory molecules CD80 and CD86 on the cell surface, as well as the upregulation of pro-inflammatory cytokine genes [46]. In addition to altering metabolism, microplastics can activate and differentiate macrophages. They promote macrophage aggregation [85] and facilitate their maturation [12]. For instance, nanoplastics can penetrate bone marrow, impairing the migration capacity of pre-osteoblasts while enhancing osteoclastogenesis of pre-osteoclasts, thereby increasing the differentiation of RAW264.7 cells into osteoclasts at the morphological and molecular levels. Furthermore, microplastics induce polarization of macrophages towards the M1 phenotype. Studies have demonstrated that exposure to PS-M/NPs alters surface markers expression on mouse macrophages [19,46]. Specifically, microplastics enhance CD80 expression in RAW264.7 cells, indicating a transition to a pro-inflammatory phenotype [7]. Some studies have also reported a concentration-dependent effect, with lower concentrations of PS-NPs inducing a weaker pro-inflammatory response [86,87]. Gu et al. [88] observed that exposure to PS-M/NPs (100 nm, 5 μm, and 200 μm, 500 μg/L) led to an increase in the proportion of M1 macrophages and a decrease in M2 macrophages in the intestines of adult zebrafish. Additionally, research examining the long-term oral intake of microplastics in mice revealed increased macrophage infiltration in the liver, significantly raising the percentage of M1 macrophages while decreasing the proportion of M2 macrophages [89]. A recent study further demonstrated that PS-NPs promote M1 polarization of mouse RAW264.7 macrophages, regardless of size, identifying 50 μg/mL as a critical concentration threshold. Exceeding this concentration significantly affects macrophage activity, promoting M1 polarization while inhibiting M2 polarization [72]. Collectively, these findings indicate that microplastics can effectively induce a dominant M1 polarization state in macrophages. The inflammatory response is a critical mechanism underlying microplastic-induced cytotoxicity [37]. Macrophages, as key immune cells involved in inflammation, have been demonstrated in various in vitro and in vivo studies to exhibit pro-inflammatory responses upon exposure to microplastics. For example, Das et al. [10] showed that PS-NPs in the air can promote the release of inflammatory proteins like tumor necrosis factor- α (TNF-α), IL-6, and IL-1β in mouse alveolar macrophages. Similarly, other research indicated that 3 μm PS-MPs can stimulate TNF-α secretion and elevate its mRNA expression levels in RAW264.7 mouse macrophage cells [61]. Additionally, PS-NPs have been shown to activate Toll-like receptor 4 (TLR4)/p38-mediated pro-inflammatory pathways in mouse microglial cells (N9 cells) [90]. Moreover, various types of microplastic particles can also induce the production of inflammatory and oxidative stress markers in macrophages, such as monocyte chemoattractant protein-1 (MCP-1), macrophage inflammatory protein-2 (CXCL2), IL-6, and heme oxygenase-1 (HMOX-1) [59]. Specifically, polytetrafluoroethylene microplastics (PTFE-MPs) have been shown to increase the secretion of TNF-α and IL-6 in the U937 macrophage cell line [91]. Huang et al. [92] further found that PP-MPs at a concentration of 100 μg/mL can promote the release of TNF-α and IL-6 from mouse macrophages. While the degree of inflammation induced by microplastics varies depending on factors such as particle type, concentration, and duration of exposure, these findings collectively support the conclusion that microplastics promote M1 polarization of macrophages and exert pro-inflammatory effects.

## Contradictory evidence and possible Explanations for the effects of microplastics on M1 polarization and pro-inflammatory responses in macrophages
However, many studies have reported that microplastics may have no significant effect on the polarization and activation of macrophages. For instance, Adler et al. [11] reported that exposure to PS-NPs did not result in any changes in the surface marker expression of human macrophages. Similarly, Stock et al. [93] investigated the effects of microplastics ranging from 1 to 10 μm on macrophage polarization and activation using the human cell line THP-1. Although some microplastics were absorbed by the macrophages, in vivo data revealed no histologically detectable lesions or inflammatory responses. These findings suggest that microplastics do not impact the differentiation or functional activation of human macrophage models. Interestingly, there is evidence that microplastics may inhibit M1 polarization of macrophages or even promote M2 polarization. One study examining the effects of microplastics on phagocytic dendritic cells and macrophages in vitro showed a downregulation of pro-inflammatory M1 macrophage markers [20]. Additionally, other studies indicated that exposure to PS-MPs significantly shifted the M1/M2 macrophage ratio in mouse placenta towards the M2 subtype [94]. As previously mentioned, the absorption and toxic effects of microplastics are shaped by their physicochemical characteristics and environmental conditions. This implies that the influence of microplastics on M1 polarization and pro-inflammatory responses in macrophages may similarly be affected by these factors. The diverse surface physicochemical characteristics of microplastics can lead to either inflammatory or anti-inflammatory effects in macrophages. Research has shown that amino-functionalized polystyrene nanoparticles (PS–NH2) with diameters ranging from 1 to 100 nm, rather than carboxylated or non-functionalized particles, are capable of activating the NLRP3 inflammasome in human macrophages, promoting the release of IL-1β [95]. In contrast, another study found that carboxylated polystyrene particles measuring 500 nm and 1000 nm also triggered the release of pro-inflammatory cytokines, including IL-6 and IL-8, in monocytes and macrophages [87]. Notably, carboxylated PS-NPs demonstrated enhanced pro-inflammatory and cytotoxic effects [96]. Conversely, Fuchs et al. [97] observed that both carboxylated and amino-modified PS-NPs inhibited the polarization of macrophage to the M2 phenotype by reducing the levels of CD200R, CD163, and IL-10, without affecting M1 markers. This indicates that the effects of nanoparticles on the polarization of macrophage may depend both on the functional groups present and other physicochemical characteristics. Additionally, Huang's research group [98] found that hydrophilic polyurethane nanoparticles exhibit surface-dependent immunosuppressive properties, inhibiting M1 polarization of macrophages by decreasing TNF-α and IL-1β production. Furthermore, the surface charge of microplastics influences the formation of a protein corona, which plays a crucial role in macrophage polarization [99]. For microplastics exposed to environmental conditions and coated with an ecological corona, this effect may be further enhanced [11]. In conclusion, evaluating the effects of microplastics on macrophage polarization requires careful consideration of several factors. These include not only the variations in macrophage types used in experiments and potential experimental errors, but also the intrinsic characteristics of the microplastics themselves, such as size and surface physicochemical properties, as well as their exposure to environmental conditions.

## Induction of oxidative stress by microplastics promotes cytotoxic endpoints in macrophages
In addition to the direct toxicity of microplastic particles to cell membranes and organelles, as well as the adverse effects resulting from their accumulation in lysosomes [45,52,88,100], microplastics primarily induce cytotoxic endpoints, such as inflammation, genotoxicity, and apoptosis, in macrophages through the induction of oxidative stress [91,79,101]. Most studies indicate that the production of reactive oxygen species (ROS) and the resulting oxidative stress are closely related to the harmful effects of microplastics, serving as both initiating and key molecular events in microplastic-induced toxicity [[102], [103], [104]]. ROS are a group of highly reactive molecules formed as a result of cellular oxidative metabolism. They serve as signaling molecules in various biological processes and are also the end products of many metabolic reactions, including superoxide anion (O2•−), hydrogen peroxide (H2O2), and hydroxyl radicals (•OH) [105]. O2•− is a common precursor of all ROS produced by cells and can rapidly dismutate to H2O2 under the catalysis of superoxide dismutase (SOD) [106,107]. While ROS help cells carry out normal physiological activities, excessive ROS can disrupt redox balance, leading to adverse effects such as oxidative stress, protein oxidation, lipid peroxidation, DNA damage, and even cell death [10,100]. Key components of the antioxidant mechanisms that protect cells from ROS-induced stress include enzymes such as glutathione peroxidase (GPX), catalase (CAT), SOD, oxidized and reduced glutathione (GSSG/GSH), and glutathione reductase (GR). Once ROS are generated within the cell, an imbalance occurs if the antioxidant mechanisms cannot compensate for oxidative stress, leading to abnormal activation of cellular signaling pathways [10]. Microplastics can stimulate ROS production through oxidative bursts and activate various cytokines [58]. Even short-term exposure to microplastics can cause a rapid increase in intracellular ROS levels, leading to membrane damage and lipid peroxidation [108]. Furthermore, the accumulation of microplastics in organs can disrupt mitochondrial function, leading to uncontrolled ROS production and the initiation of inflammatory signaling cascades and various forms of cell death [10]. Several studies suggest that ROS-induced oxidative stress is a critical factor in the cytotoxicity associated with PS-NPs [109,110]. For macrophages, the two main endogenous sources of O2•− and H2O2 are the cytosolic NADPH oxidase (NOX) and mitochondria [[111], [112], [113]]. Following exposure to microplastics, macrophages rapidly internalize the ingested particles to facilitate their clearance. NOX and/or other enzymes generate O2•− and H2O2 [105,114], which subsequently accumulate in the mitochondria. In this context, microplastics compromise mitochondrial integrity, leading to an increased production of mitochondrial reactive oxygen species (mtROS) [115]. Both O2•− and H2O2 play roles in signal transduction and act as key mediators driving oxidative stress cascades [102]. Therefore, the ROS produced by macrophages not only play a critical role in antimicrobial defense but also regulate macrophage function by acting as important signaling molecules [116]. Microplastics can promote adverse outcomes in macrophages by enhancing ROS generation and altering metabolic characteristics [63,117,74]. Exposure to PS-NPs (500 μg/mL) induces oxidative stress in human macrophages and reduces cell proliferation [21]. PP particles smaller than 20 μm exhibit cytotoxicity to Raw 264.7 cells, with this toxicity being caused by increased ROS levels, occurring in a size- and concentration-dependent manner [118]. To further investigate the role of ROS in PS-NPs-induced necroptosis of macrophages, Fan et al. found that exposure to PS-NPs significantly downregulated the activity of the antioxidant SOD, total thiols (-SH), and GSH, while significantly upregulating the levels of the oxidative product malondialdehyde (MDA) in a dose-dependent manner. PS-NPs accumulate in the mitochondria of RAW 264.7 cells, and this accumulation leads to severe mitochondrial dysfunction, including the disturbance of complex I on the electron transport chain, membrane hyperpolarization, and ATP mutation, ultimately favoring the upregulation of mtROS to trigger necroptosis [115]. There is also evidence that ROS generated by PS-NH2 directly or indirectly affect the endoplasmic reticulum homeostasis and protein folding in macrophages, leading to endoplasmic reticulum stress and subsequent autophagic cell death [74]. PS-NPs may also induce microglial inflammatory responses and ferroptosis by promoting lipid peroxidation and ROS accumulation [119]. When exposed to NPs, the intracellular ROS levels in microglia significantly increase, while GSH and SOD levels decrease, and MDA levels rise. Pre-treatment with the ROS inhibitor N-acetylcysteine (NAC) significantly reduces the expression of MDA, while the activities of SOD and GSH are markedly increased. Furthermore, experimental results indicate that NP-induced inflammatory responses and ferroptosis are mediated by ROS. This suggests that ROS plays a critical role in the inflammation and ferroptosis of macrophages induced by microplastics [119]. Furthermore, the ROS produced by macrophages can coordinate immune responses through redox signaling in various ways, such as regulating the secretion of pro-inflammatory cytokines, activating inflammasomes, and coordinating subsequent adaptive immune responses through antigen presentation [[120], [121], [122]]. KC et al. [91] exposed six different human cell lines, including U937 and THP-1 macrophages, to two sizes of irregularly shaped PTFE-MPs with average diameters of 6.0 or 31.7 μm. They found that PTFE-MPs increased ROS levels across all tested cell lines, particularly in macrophages, and activated the ERK pathway, ultimately inducing oxidative stress and inflammation. Excessive ROS production is known to be a major contributor to the pathogenesis of inflammation and is associated with the progression of various inflammatory diseases [123]. Studies on nanoplastic-induced inflammation in macrophages have shown that nanoplastics can induce ROS production and activate the mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) and nuclear factor kappa B (NF-κB) pathways, leading to an upregulation of pro-inflammatory cytokines such as IL-6 and TNF-α [96]. Additionally, research has found that exposure to PS-NPs can lead to a decrease in mitochondrial membrane potential, accumulation of ROS, and calcium overload in RAW 264.7 cells. At elevated levels of ROS, this may result in mitochondrial dysfunction and the release of mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA). The free mtDNA within the cell can be recognized by cyclic GMP-AMP (cGAMP), activating the cGAS-STING signaling pathway associated with innate immunity [124]. Furthermore, PS-NPs can also induce the expression of downstream inflammatory factors, such as NF-κB, through the cGAS-STING pathway, leading to inflammation [125]. Jeon et al. [79] found a strong correlation between the intrinsic ROS-generating potential of microplastics and cytotoxic endpoints, including cytotoxicity and pro-inflammatory cytokines in THP-1 macrophages. However, some studies reported no increase in ROS production in macrophages after exposure to PS-NPs, which may be attributed to factors such as microplastic heterogeneity, concentration, exposure duration, and their effects on different tissue or cell types [11,104]. Among ROS, H2O2 is a promising candidate as a signaling messenger for cell death due to its relative stability, with a half-life of a few seconds. H2O2 easily penetrates cell membranes, allowing it to diffuse into neighboring cells and react with their components. The oxidants released by dying cells may kill adjacent cells through a bystander effect [126]. Thubagere et al. [127] found that nanoplastics can significantly impact cell viability in the CACO-2 intestinal membrane model by triggering apoptosis in individual cells, leading to oxidative stress that releases H2O2 into the extracellular environment and induces apoptosis in nearby cells. For macrophages, exposure to microplastics can generate substantial ROS, potentially affecting the function and health of surrounding cells through a similar bystander effect. While PS-NPs do not directly induce cytotoxicity in hepatocytes, they may upregulate ROS production and trigger redox-sensitive necroptosis in macrophages when co-cultured with RAW 264.7 cells, enhancing crosstalk between macrophages and hepatocytes and resulting in hepatocyte damage [115]. However, further evidence is needed to support the claim that microplastic exposure directly leads to increased ROS in the extracellular space of macrophages, making the exploration of microplastics’ impact on ROS levels in the macrophage microenvironment a promising direction for future research. ROS play a pivotal role in regulating intracellular redox signaling processes, particularly targeting redox-sensitive –SH. These –SH group, being highly reactive components within proteins, are susceptible to oxidation, leading to changes in protein structure and function. When macrophages exposed to MPs, studies have observed a decrease in –SH levels, which can be attributed to the oxidative stress induced by ROS [115]. Chiu et al. found that MP-induced ROS contribute to the formation of protein misfolding aggregates, and induce endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress. Additionally, ROS phosphorylate AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) and inhibit the AKT/mammalian target of rapamycin (mTOR) pathway. Both of these actions potentiate autophagic cell death [74]. During this process, ROS induce the oxidation of cysteine residues in AMPK, leading to further phosphorylation of active AMPK [128]. Furthermore, p62, a proteolytic autophagy receptor, is upregulated in response to MPs, particularly in response to H2O2. Under these conditions, p62 forms disulfide-linked conjugates, which contribute to the activation of autophagy [128]. The ingestion of MPs by macrophages leads to an overproduction of ROS, disrupting the cellular redox balance. In addition to ROS, nitric oxide (NO) is another important oxidative stress signaling molecule that plays a significant role in the inflammatory responses of macrophages. Following exposure to microplastics, increases in both ROS and NO levels in vivo and in vitro contribute to oxidative stress [91]. Research has found that PS-M/NPs stimulate NO production in mouse RAW264.7 cells in a dose-dependent manner by increasing the activity of nitric oxide synthase (NOS) [61]. NO reacts with superoxide to form peroxynitrite (ONOO−), a potent biological oxidant that affects mitochondrial function and triggers cell death through oxidative and nitrative reactions, potentially mediating severe bystander tissue damage [129]. The upregulation of NOS and accumulation of ROS induced by microplastics create the conditions for the generation of ONOO−. Under light irradiation, nitrogen-containing microplastics (N-MPs) will form persistent aminoxyl radicals (PAORs) and reactive nitrogen species (RNS). Nitric oxide radicals (•NO) generated by the photolysis of nitrone groups can react simultaneously with peroxyl radicals and superoxide anion radicals (O2•−), yielding nitrogen dioxide radicals (•NO2) and ONOO− respectively [130]. Pezzotti et al. [131] observed via specific nitrative stress-sensing dyes and high-resolution fluorescence microscopy that silicon nitride (Si3N4)-modified polymethylmethacrylate (PMMA) composites induce ONOO− radical accumulation in Candida albicans mitochondria, indicating that Si3N4-endowed PMMA surface chemistry mimics macrophage antifungal mechanisms, inducing NO and O2•− to react and form candidacidal ONOO−. Additionally, microplastic digestive clearance generates extensive RNS. Peng et al. [132] used near-infrared spectroscopy (NIR) to quantify Tenebrio molitor biodegradation kinetics of PS-MPs and found increased ONOO− levels during larval degradation of small (<30 μm) and large (<300 μm) PS-MPs, with larvae instinctively enhancing and heterogeneously redistributing intestinal ONOO− in response to MP biodegradation. The formation of ONOO− by macrophages represents a mechanism of cytotoxic effect that requires immune stimulation with cytokines that induce iNOS expression [133]. Additionally, exposure to nanoplastics has been shown to significantly increase the mRNA levels of iNOS in mouse microglia [90]. Taken together, these findings suggest that NO may serve as an additional mechanism through which microplastics exert pro-inflammatory effects on macrophages. It links the NOS-mediated generation of NO, the accumulation of ROS, and the ONOO−-related oxidative/nitrative stress.

## The impact of microplastics on macrophages through gut microbiota
Besides the direct pathological and physiological effects of microplastics, it is important to highlight that many environmental microplastics contain additives. These additives can promote the adhesion and growth of bacterial pathogens on or within the particles, transforming microplastics into potential carriers of microbial toxicity. This raises concerns about the further toxic effects that may occur when these particles cross human biological barriers [1,18]. Microplastics can act as a Trojan horse for foreign pathogens, adversely affecting the resident microbiota of organisms and leading to dysbiosis in the gut, nose, and lungs [134,135]. For instance, Multiple studies have demonstrated that long-term exposure to microplastics in mice leads to dysbiosis, impaired intestinal barrier function, and metabolic disorders [18,136]. Environmental microplastics tend to enrich opportunistic pathogens decreasing the abundance of beneficial bacteria [137]. The relationship between gut probiotics and intestinal barrier integrity underscores that dysbiosis plays a significant indirect role in microplastic-induced intestinal dysfunction [138,139]. Furthermore, dysbiosis and intestinal dysfunction induced by microplastics can have widespread systemic effects on various host systems, including the digestive, immune, hematopoietic, nervous, and reproductive systems [18,[140], [141], [142], [143], [144]]. Studies have demonstrated that PS-MPs disrupt the gut microbiome, compromise the intestinal barrier, increase peripheral inflammation, and alter serum metabolites profiles. Additionally, Lipopolysaccharides (LPS) resulting from dysbiosis can activate macrophage TLR4, leading to the expression of hypoxia-inducible factor 1-alpha (HIF-1α). This activation initiates aerobic glycolysis, which enhances ATP production and promotes a pro-inflammatory phenotype in macrophages [145]. Importantly, research indicates that addressing the dysbiotic gut microbiome caused by PS-MPs can significantly reduce serum concentrations of LPS, IL-1β, IL-6, and TNF-α. This reduction may help prevent intestinal barrier damage and peripheral inflammation induced by PS-MPs. Furthermore, such interventions can inhibit the TLR4/MyD88/NF-κB pathway and thereby reducing neuroinflammation [137]. As previously mentioned, the innate immune system serves as the first line of defense against microbial and microplastic pollution, with macrophages playing a critical role in this response. Acting as gatekeepers, macrophages directly interact with microplastics, microorganisms, and their metabolic byproducts, effectively capturing and eliminating these “criminals” or “hit-and-run offenders”. Moreover, macrophages can mount an immune response to the metabolic products resulting from the interaction between microplastics and microorganisms. They adapt to changes in the microenvironment by expressing various functional programs tailored to the specific challenges they encounter. Therefore, long-term exposure to microplastics can lead to dysbiosis and metabolic disorders, which may adversely affect the functional activities of macrophages (Fig. 3). Importantly, exposure to PS-NPs induced the stimulation of BV2 microglial cells, resulting in noticeable cell body enlargement, excessive ROS production, and increased secretion of TNF-α and IL-1β. Additionally, the conditioned medium from BV2 cells exposed to PS-NPs caused significant damage to mouse neuronal HT-22 cells. Microplastics can also induce gut dysbiosis, leading to neuronal damage by interfering with the microbiome-gut-brain axis [143,221,222]. Gut dysbiosis can increase intestinal permeability, precede changes in central nervous system immunity and trigger neuroinflammation [223]. The activation of microglia and the resulting immune alterations can also arise as a secondary effect to microplastic-induced gut dysbiosis [143]. Microplastics can trigger inflammatory signals in gut macrophages, leading to adverse effects on the nervous system through the gut-brain axis. Yang et al. [7] found that nanoplastics can induce lysosomal damage, triggering macrophage reprogramming to produce intestinal IL-1β. Furthermore, signaling of IL-1β originating from the gut can impact brain immune responses, causing activation of microglia and differentiation of Th17 cells, which may ultimately contribute to cognitive decline and impairments in short-term memory in mice [7].

## Pulmonary toxicity
Various types and shapes of microplastics have been detected in human lung tissues [224,225]. After inhalation, microplastics navigate from the nasal cavity through the respiratory tract to reach the alveoli, where gas exchange occurs in the lungs. Although nasal hairs can block larger particles, and mucus cilia can trap them for clearance through coughing or phlegm, some microplastics may accumulate deep in the lungs or even enter the bloodstream. Particles exceeding than 10 μm usually get trapped in the upper respiratory tract, while those smaller than 10 μm are capable of reaching the bronchioles. Additionally, particles smaller than 2.5 μm, including ultrafine particles, can infiltrate the alveoli [226]. Microplastics can disrupt the biophysical functions of lung surfactants and compromise the structural integrity of the alveoli and the barrier function of the airways. Additionally, microplastics that settle deep within the respiratory tract can trigger localized pro-inflammatory responses facilitated by macrophages or epithelial cells. This leads to the generation of ROS, release of inflammatory mediators, and apoptosis, contributing to both acute and chronic respiratory diseases [[227], [228], [229], [230], [231]]. Studies have shown that PS-MPs can induce cytotoxicity and inflammation in human lung epithelial cells by production the formation of ROS [228]. The activation of the TLR4 pathway, along with NF-κB, and the NLRP3 inflammasome, has been linked to PS-MP-induced lung inflammation [232]. Furthermore, NPs trigger mitochondrial damage, ROS-induced oxidative stress, apoptosis, necrosis, and inflammation while activating the cGAS-STING signaling pathway, resulting in notable pulmonary fibrosis [124,233]. Moreover, a significant portion of microplastics inhaled through the respiratory tract has been detected in extrapulmonary tissues, including blood, bone marrow, liver, brain, heart, spleen, and kidneys. This indicates that microplastics may transfer from the alveoli to these extrapulmonary organs via endocytosis by alveolar macrophages into the bloodstream [227]. Macrophages located on the epithelial surface of the lungs serve as a crucial first line of defense, as they are immersed in the surface lining layer and directly exposed to environmental pathogens [234]. They play essential roles in maintaining lung homeostasis, clearing pathogens, and regulating immune responses, significantly influencing both acute and chronic lung diseases [235]. Consequently, microplastics can directly induce a range of pulmonary toxicity symptoms through their interaction with macrophages. Lu et al. [85] found that inhaling microplastics in normal mice led to the infiltration of inflammatory cells in the lungs, especially macrophages aggregation, elevated TNF-α levels in alveolar lavage fluid, and increased IgG1 production. In mice with asthma, microplastics inhalation resulted in more macrophage aggregation, heightened mucus production, and worsened asthma symptoms due to greater inflammatory cell infiltration. Furthermore, exposure to PS-MPs can alter the extracellular matrix (ECM) composition in macrophages, leading to ECM degradation and worsening emphysema [157].

## Therapies targeting microplastic-macrophage axis and microplastic-gut microbiota-macrophage axis-induced diseases
Microplastics pose significant hazards to different organs and tissues and may also contribute to the onset of various inflammatory diseases. Microplastics can even influence cancer progression by altering the tumor microenvironment and impairing immune surveillance, thereby promoting tumorigenesis and metastasis [236]. Studies have shown that cancer-specific proteins can enhance the phagocytosis of nanoparticles by human macrophages, leading to a strong pro-inflammatory response that contributes to tumor promotion [75]. Furthermore, the long-term chronic inflammation induced by microplastics in vivo can significantly alter the tumor microenvironment, where macrophages in the inflammatory milieu may promote the growth and survival of tumor cells by secreting growth factors and cytokines [237]. However, further evidence is needed to elucidate the exact mechanisms by which microplastics affect the direct involvement of macrophages in tumor development. The potential toxicity of microplastics primarily stems from oxidative stress and inflammatory responses that occur following exposure and ingestion [238,55]. As the primary line of defense against pathogen invasion, macrophages are essential in initiating immune responses and are actively engaged in the absorption, distribution, and clearance of microplastics within the body. Consequently, therapies that target macrophages may effectively mitigate the health risks linked to microplastics. Research has demonstrated the use of nanotechnology aimed at macrophages in the diagnosis and treatment of atherosclerosis [239]. By employing targeted nanoparticles, researchers can deliver anti-inflammatory drugs or regulatory factors directly to macrophages, thereby reducing the inflammatory responses triggered by microplastics. Moreover, studies suggest that functionalized nanoparticles can shift macrophage polarization from M1 to M2, which is essential for restoring immune balance in patients with cancer or chronic inflammation [97]. Thus, using functionalized nanoparticles to shift macrophages from the M1 to the M2 polarization state can promote tissue repair and restore immune equilibrium. This reprogramming not only enhances the ability of macrophages to clear microplastics but also decreases the risk of chronic inflammation and tissue damage associated with microplastics. In summary, targeting macrophages, the first line of defense against microplastics, emerges as a promising therapeutic strategy in precision medicine. On one hand, various macrophage-associated biomarkers can serve as key diagnostic tools for disease identification; on the other hand, multiple proteins related to macrophages can become effective targets for precision treatments of various diseases. Research has demonstrated that microplastics can disrupt gut ecology, while the gut microbiota can influence the degradation of these microplastics. Different microorganisms, including bacteria, fungi, bacterial consortia, and biofilms, found in various ecological environments possess the capability to degrade different forms of microplastics [240,241]. Additionally, certain microorganisms present within the body have been reported to contribute to this degradation process [242]. The gut microbiota facilitates microplastics breakdown through enzymatic catalytic processes, such as biodeterioration, fragmentation, assimilation, and mineralization [243,244]. During these processes, microplastics gradually decompose into small molecular oxidation metabolites such as carbon dioxide, water, methane, and nitrogen [245]. Therefore, introducing specific microbial communities can improve the breakdown of microplastics, thereby mitigating their disruptive impacts on the gut microbiome. Importantly, the presence of microplastics can induce dysbiosis and metabolic disorders within the gut microbiota, leading to alterations in macrophage metabolic functions. These changes may trigger a cascade of organ and tissue damage associated with macrophage dysfunction. Consequently, modulating the gut ecosystem and inhibiting the pro-inflammatory properties of macrophages may effectively reduce the risk of organ damage induced by microplastics. Xu et al. [246] found that resveratrol could alleviate colitis in mice by enhancing the composition and diversity of the microbiota, as well as reducing metabolic disorders. This effect is closely linked to macrophage polarization mediated by arginine metabolism, highlighting the microbiota-macrophage-arginine metabolism axis as a potential target for treating intestinal inflammation. Furthermore, research by Jia et al. [247] indicated that the potential probiotic Lactobacillus johnsonii could activate macrophages and stimulate the release of IL-10 through the TLR1/2-STAT3 pathway, thereby alleviating experimental colitis. Additionally, studies by You et al. [248] revealed that treating human peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs) with Lactobacillus fermentum strains KBL374 or KBL375 reduced levels of inflammatory cytokines IL-2, interferon-γ (ΙFΝγ), IL-4, IL-13, and IL-17A, while increasing levels of the anti-inflammatory cytokine IL-10. In mouse models, administration of these strains reshaped and increased the variety of the gut microbiota, particularly enhancing the prevalence of beneficial microorganisms such as Lactobacillus and Akkermansia spp. In summary, probiotics have a significant impact not only on addressing microplastic-induced gut dysbiosis but also as immunomodulators and anti-inflammatory agents targeting macrophage-related therapies for intestinal inflammation. Therefore, targeting the gut microbiota-macrophage axis presents a promising treatment strategy for both clearing microplastics from the body and improving macrophage function, ultimately reducing the risk of chronic inflammation and tissue damage associated with microplastics. This approach offers novel perspectives on the prevention and treatment of microplastic-induced diseases, holding significant potential for clinical applications.

## Future perspectives and conclusions
Despite the widespread recognition of human exposure to microplastics and their accumulation in the body, the fate of microplastics within human organ systems remains a topic of ongoing debate. This controversy primarily stems from the unclear health impacts of microplastics that are ingested through various routes, including inhalation, food consumption, nutrient transfer, or skin contact. Additionally, significant differences exist between microplastics found in nature and those synthesized in laboratories, particularly regarding their chemical characteristics such as size, shape, surface charge, and concentration. These variations complicate the assessment of their toxicity (Table 3). The complexity of this issue is further heightened by differences in human physiology across various age groups and health conditions, as well as the intricate metabolic processes involved. To address these potential health risks, it is crucial to conduct further in vivo and in vitro studies while also strengthening environmental management and public health education [249]. Reducing exposure and contact pathways is crucial for lowering risks associated with microplastics. Governments should promote effective management strategies, implement recycling policies, and foster the development of innovative technologies. This includes creating environmentally friendly materials to replace synthetic polymers, improving waste management systems, and utilizing advanced filtration technologies and detoxification methods for plastic waste [10,29]. Moreover, comprehensive risk assessments are necessary [37,250]. Establishing standardized methods for the characterization, detection, and toxicological study of microplastics will be vital. Developing effective technologies for accurately identifying, quantifying, and dynamically tracking microplastics and their intracellular localization within biological systems is also important. Integrating multi-omics analyses with toxicity studies can help identify highly specific and sensitive biomarkers in both in vivo and in vitro samples. Additionally, there is a need to focus on developing targeted therapeutics aimed at the microplastic-macrophage axis and the microplastic-gut microbiota-macrophage axis. Most existing studies have linked microplastic exposure to various biomarkers of cytotoxicity, such as inflammation, oxidative stress, genotoxicity, and apoptosis, while exploring the potential hazards across different organ systems. However, evidence regarding specific cellular mechanisms and key genes or molecular pathways remains insufficient, and significant gaps exist in both in vivo and in vitro research, sometimes yielding contradictory results. This review presents new perspectives and interpretations of the potential hazards associated with human exposure to microplastics based on existing evidence, bridging organ boundaries and scientific silos. It discusses effective targeting of pathogenic modules, providing important perspectives for the prevention, assessment, and treatment of microplastic-related harms.
